reviews.content:
The bad:  the homework requirements are left with intentional vagueness.  It wasn't until midway through the semester that it was clarified that this was by design and that Steve's philosophy is that in the real world there is ambiguity, so programmers will be expected to apply their own judgment in assumptions when writing a program.  Having worked in cyber security, I don't totally agree... but that being said, it's good to know upfront that you have a lot of latitude in defining the requirements so long as you document your decisions in your readme.

The assignments themselves were time consuming, although not necessarily hard.  The thought process is different than most other programming classes: you can't merely write a program to fulfill an outcome, and have to consider how the program can be exploited by attackers.  Your goal in writing is to consider the flaws and add robustness to reduce exploit vectors.

The midterm and final were open notes/open book and scenario based, so it wasn't a matter of regurgitating material as you had to consider circumstances and apply what was covered in lecture.  More CS courses should adopt this format.    

The lectures were fantastic, and kept pace with real world developments in security.  The class was at a particularly interesting time late in the 2016 election season when there was a lot of pub about Hillary Clinton's E-mail server and the hacking of the DNC E-mails.  Steve's experience dates back decades and he has a lot of interesting stories which compelled me to research further on my own after class.
reviews.workload: Four assignments, two week turnaround for each.  They required a good bit of time, but nothing that was rocket science.

reviews.content:
I mostly agree with the reviews below but would add that Bellovin curves down (almost the entire class would have gotten an A or A- this semester based on numerical scores and so to change this a 93 was downgraded to a B+). 

A larger issue not mentioned here is that the assignments lacked foresight and the grading seemed arbitrary. There were several instances when instructions had to be clarified at the last minute before something was due or the rubric itself was incorrect and the grade assigned needed to be revised. 

A fourth homework was assigned during the week of final exams which should have been announced earlier or released during the semester. I also think it's better policy to make the course requirements more challenging and curve up than to make the requirements trivial and to curve down (this is especially true when based on the results of a final that students cannot see since the semester is over).

Not an incredibly demanding course but not particularly substantive or rewarding either.
reviews.workload: four programming assignments in c/c++ that take a fair amount of time, midterm and final are open book/open notes

reviews.content:
I'm surprised this course doesn't have more positive reviews. It should. It's a lot of fun and you learn a good amount. The course essentially covers the whole spectrum when it comes to building a secure computer system. We touch on everything from buffer overflows, to real world cryptography issues, to social engineering attacks. This gave us a good overview of what security is about in a computing setting.

Prof Bellovin is great. He's clearly extremely passionate amount the material and does a good job presenting it. He's a bit of a legend in the computer security world, and so has lots of great stories to tell; some of them even made us laugh. 

Definitely recommended.
reviews.workload: Not too bad. We had four assignments in total. 3 were about building a secure program (each assignment focused on a different aspect of security). The last assignment was hacking a program which was fun.

reviews.content: Security Architecture is a great idea for a course, but I don't like how such an important topic gets watered down so much. In lecture, we just go over a bunch of security concepts like permissions and buffer overflows at a high level. Prof. Bellovin seems to avoid going into technical details when possible, so the lectures are not very information dense. (When I miss class, I usually watch at 1.25x and that speed feels about right.) Some lectures, Prof. Bellovin brings out his funny side and cracks a bunch of jokes, which is pretty nice.
reviews.workload:
Workload: very light. Only 4 homeworks. The three programming assignments remind me of labs in AP. We used C or C++ to implement some security-critical toy program like a print spooler or a command parser/sanitizer. These were kind of interesting, but I think it would be more fun if we knew that the graders would try to exploit our programs instead of grading them based on a checklist of features / requirements. In the last one, we get a binary and are told to attack it (more open ended). 

I didn't like the way the homeworks were bunched up at the end. We nearly got through the first half of the semester without turning in anything.

reviews.content:
I would recommend this class to anyone except the following two groups:

1) You hate programming in C/C++
2) Thinking "outside the box" and "thinking like the bad guy" isn't your thing.

Otherwise, I heartily recommend the course. Professor Bellovin's lectures are entertaining -- I actually looked forward to going to the lectures. His lectures are obviously well prepared; he seems to reuse the same slides but updates them the night before to keep them relevant. The lectures are organized and lively -- with a nice touch of sarcasm. 

The assignments are mostly about building a secure program that manages files. Watch out -- just because you "meet the specs" doesn't mean you will get full credit (or even a good grade). Unlike other classes where the professor would promise "you can assume you will get proper input," here you can assume the graders will be very creative about how they can cause your program to produce errors. You have to validate inputs like crazy. Writing the actual program isn't hard, but you will use some unusual/unfamiliar c libraries so don't start too late because you need a day or two to familiarize yourself with the documentation. Definitely do assignment 0 to get your C/C++ up to scratch (and you WILL need it for assignment 1). If you start a week early on pretty much any assignment, it will be a breeze. If you start 2-3 days before the deadline, you will be pulling consecutive late-nighters. The assignments aren't cakewalk, but they aren't complicated or ambitious either.

The midterm and final are subjective (and easy), but graded fairly. They accept a lot of answers if the justification is good. They are still published on earlier versions of the course website if you want to have an idea of what they are like. If you know the lectures, can mix the concepts together, and can "think like a bad guy" you will do well on the midterms with little studying. If you pay attention in lecture and go over the slides, you will do well on the test. 

Overall, this is a really solid course, interesting, and not burdensome. I recommend it.
reviews.workload: On a scale of 1-10 with 10 being the hardest, I'd say 3-5 depending on your background and how interesting security is to you.

reviews.content:
This course is fairly simple, and a good bet if you are trying to improve your GPA.

4-5 fairly easy, (written + programming) assignments (50%) that will be as simple or as complex as you want them to be; however, putting in extra effort to write an extraordinary program will not fetch you extra credits.

Easy mid-term (20%) and finals (30%) that contain only open-ended, "open to interpretation" questions. There are no right or wrong answers to most of the questions. You are supposed to integrate all your knowledge to answer the questions, but basically the answers are so downright simplistic (and amusing) that they might not strike you at all. That is, if you have a rough idea of what has been taught in the class, and use appropriate terms from the slides and suggested reading materials while answering, and mention that your answer assumes "so-and-so", you can hardly get it wrong. 

The whole course is about applying common sense. I have to say that I didn't learn anything spectacular in this course. I goofed up in the midterms because I didn't apply "enough" common sense, and did very well in everything else. And I got an A- with a 92%, so that should say it all.
reviews.workload: Low to medium.

reviews.content:
Professor Bellovin is an engaging and well-prepared lecturer.  He's got a good sense of humor, he can draw you in to the material, and when he does he explains it very clearly.  Of course, the material is intrinsically interesting, varied and with a strong focus on real-world security incidents.

I'd recommend the course, but there are some caveats.  There's no single textbook and the readings, while usually interesting, vary greatly in terms of how thoroughly they cover their subjects.  On top of that, while lecture notes are posted online, they usually provide only a broad outline of what Bellovin says in class, so it can be hard to find reference material for homeworks or for studying if you missed a class or didn't take good notes.

Also, Bellovin appears to be something of a big shot in the computer security world outside of academia (eg., helped write Usenet back in the day, won the 2007 NIST / NASA security award).  This is kind of cool, but involves him missing a relatively large number of classes to travel to conferences and so on.  When he's gone, classes are taught by the TA, and at least in our case, the TA was a non-native English speaker and a bad lecturer.
reviews.workload: 4 homeworks, which make up 50% of the grade, plus a midterm and a final.  The midterm and the final are relatively easy if you've gone to a reasonable number of the lectures and done a reasonable amount of the reading; the questions are straightforward.  Each homework has a written part and a programming part.  The homeworks are moderately difficult and time-consuming, about the average for a Columbia comp sci class, but are graded particularly harshly.  There is also a tough lateness policy, and no freebies / dropping lowest grade / etc.  If the class is curved, it doesn't change much.

reviews.content: Computer Science is a difficult topic to lecture. Blaer truly embodies that. His teaching is definitely difficult to keep up with because its just so boring. He's monotone, but not monotone in a quiet kinda way--monotone in a LOUD kinda way. He does record his lectures and give late days for assignments which are a huge plus and it seems like he understands that people go through things/make mistakes.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
Weekly ZyBooks assignments--superrrr helpful and a great investment for the class. Not a TON of work and answers are visible for help.

Weekly Codio/Gradescope assignments which are not too difficult as well.

reviews.content: I enjoyed Blaer's lectures, though they can be a little slow-paced. He's clear, thorough, and funny. Homework is a little tricky sometimes, just go to TA office hours when needed. Exams are easier than the homework in my opinion––they're largely straight-forward and Blaer literally walks through question-by-question what will be on the exam. Just pay attention and you'll be fine. Blaer sets a good foundation for an essential concept for computer science students.
reviews.workload: Homework took ~3-4 hours/week. Preparing for ~3-5 hours for an exam is fine.

reviews.content: I had heard good things about Blaer, and he fit most of the descriptions. He records his lectures which is great for reviewing more difficult concepts while studying. Pretty chill teacher and tells at least 1 joke or story a class. Direct and clear teaching style, explains concepts, gives examples, and then walks through it in code. The content was fine, more complex topics given in the later half so it's important to stay on top of things but overall not too difficult if you're willing to put in the work.
reviews.workload:
10 assignments (half written, half coding, given in pairs) with about 2 weeks to submit each pair. Assignments - 50%, midterm - 20%, final - 30%. 

The assignments are fair, they just may take a bit of time or extra thinking to complete. The exams I also thing are fair, you just need to seriously know the concepts and may have to memorize a bit of code for algorithms. He does a review session before the exam so you know what to study, and as long as you seriously follow it, you should be good.

reviews.content: Prof Blaer is great. His lectures are always interesting, and he sometimes sidetracks with somewhat related, funny stories. His lectures alternate between explaining the math behind an algorithm and implementing it in code. He tells you exactly what is expected of you, so as long as you pay attention and complete assignments, you will do fine. I took this class without having taken Intro Java, although I did take AP CSA in high school. He does warn against skipping Intro Java, but if you put in the work, it's completely manageable.
reviews.workload: 20% midterm, 30% final, 50% for 10 homework assignments. Half of the homeworks are written assignments, and half are coding. He gives about 2 weeks to complete each pair of assignments (one written, one code). He tells you exactly what will be on the exams, but he doesn't give practice exams.

reviews.content: Blaer is the goat. Had him for Intro to Java and Data Structures. His lectures are clear and easy to follow, and they're all recorded. I will say this course is pretty data structures theory focused, as in symbolic/pen-and-paper representations of the data structures, and not very focused on the coding aspect. This makes the class easier, but I wish we were given more opportunities to practice coding so the material would be actually useful.
reviews.workload: imo the midterm and final were easier the than the intro to java exams. The content was more straightforward, Blaer basically lays out what you need to know in a review sheet before the exams. 10 homeworks, assigned in pairs (1 written, 1 programming). One pair is dropped.

reviews.content: Honestly, I learned a lot in this class but it took a few of the harder coding assignments to make sense. Also, I really reccomend office hours as they helped me a lot. This class starts with what I feel like is sort of a weed out written homework but then gets into java and moves relatively slowly for thr first few weeks. Everything related to obect orientation in java and classes/objects is kind of rushed as well as arrays and that makes the midterm a little harder, so I would reccomend reading/working ahead to the sections up until arrays so that there's more time to process some of this. Homeworks 6 and 8 are the hardest but if you spend the time doing them the rest of this class will make sense and become a lot easier. Really the key is learning how to debug and understanding objet orientation in java as well as how java as a laguage functions. If you do the harder homeworks well the other concepts will be relatively easy because they just build on the basics. Also the last portion of this class helps to prepare you for data structures so it actually is relatively important as well. There are really great office hours for this class, and I really enjoyed this class in the end. I found professor Blaer to be very good overall, but some of the concepts he really doesn't go into depth on so I would do the readings before class. Also, grading and assignments being released can be disorganized at times but it was never a huge issue for me.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science in Java

reviews.workload: 10 homeworks 5 written 5 coding, readings on zybooks, and then a midterm and final. Start homeworks early if you can, for exams he tells you roughly what is on it but what that maps to often is relativley unexpected for people so really review every topic and the zybooks before exams.

reviews.content: Blaer teaches very well and clearly. He wants every student to do well and this comes across. He is down to earth and does his best to make class interesting and entertaining through stories and jokes.
reviews.workload: 10 homework assignments (5 written, 5 coding), lowest two are dropped. The workload is very manageable. One midterm and final which are very fair (midterm average was 74.7%). He tells most of what are on the tests so they are easy to prepare for. His TAs are wonderful and are so helpful during office hours. The course is curved to a B+/A- average.

reviews.content: Everyone told me such great things about Professor Blaer, and honestly he sets the bar really low for doing well in the class. He's super engaging in class and him + the TAs always care about your work and will respond to any emails / Ed Discussions. Content is a little difficult if you haven't taken a Java course before, but he does explain things if you haven't.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Work was so easy and grading was incredibly fair. Spent about 2 hours max per week on this class and maybe 3-4 hours studying for the midterms/finals just to review content.

reviews.content:
Disclaimer is that I have never touched cs before. Ever. So this course was definitely a challenge. Blaer is friendly, straightforward, hilarious in lectures at times, but he definitely does sort of assume a foundational type of knowledge on how code works. I didn't feel like we had time to absorb the foundations before starting on subtopics. After I got the basic principles in my head though, it went much better, and I did well starting from the midterms. I never showed up to the lectures in person, personally found it much more helpful to rewatch the recordings at 2x speed, coding along, pausing and replaying parts at my own pace. Lecture content feels a little disjointed at first, not always clear how everything connects, so you do need to read and do! the! ZyBooks! Not gonna lie though, this course would've taken me a lot longer if it weren't for me basically using GPT4 as an on demand tutor/TA, helping explain to me textbook and lecture content, as well as providing more practice questions. 

Overall still a good course. Feel very meh about the subject though, just wanted to try.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Assignments were perfectly doable on my own, with minor clarification from TAs, as long as I had a good grasp of the lecture and textbook content. Grading is fine. Blaer's very clear about when regrade requests are due, just get them in before then and they'll handle it. Lowest even and lowest odd numbered HW assignment grade is also dropped (very appreciated, given that I couldn't turn 2 assignments in even by the late deadline). Finals was tough but with a lot of studying it also went fine.

reviews.content:
Okay, so disclaimer, I never did Java before this class, but I do have programming experience in Python, which made it easier for me to grasp Java concepts and figure out coding logic.

 For starters, I do not really like Blaer's teaching style, its kinda all over the place and there arent any slides or anything. Its more like he codes and talks. Honestly, I did not find it helpful to go to lecture because of this. I found it a better use of my time to just learn Java on my own. 

The homeworks do progressively get harder and more time consuming, so my advice is to start early and go to TA OH. Some TAs are better than others imo cuz some of them would not even know what the assignment is about while others were more prepared to answer questions, so find out which TAs work better for you. Also, check EDStem while doing HW, because often the HW instructions are not very specific and there will be new requirements that are not mentioned in the HW instructions that you only find out about because someone else asked about it on ED Stem.

I do like that Blaer tells you what topics are going to be on the exam before hand so that you know what to really drill down for the exam. I only went to Blaer's OH one time, and he was lowkey condescending. I asked my question in a respectful manner so I think the rudeness was uncalled for.  If many people are saying hes unapproachable then I doubt this was just a one time thing. 

Grading for this class is chill though, its curved well. I ended up with an A w a raw of 92. Class average was like a 70 for the final and midterm.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.content:
As someone with little experience in Java, this class was definitely difficult. I would only take this course if you are seriously interested in majoring/minoring in CS - it is not just an elective you can push off to the side. I took COMS1004 to see if I wanted to major in CS and realized it wasn't for me, so the last couple of months were a pain to get through because the homework gets harder and harder. Honesty, everything after the midterm dramatically increased in difficulty. I also found the homework to be inordinately difficult compared to the exams. Expect to spend 5-10 hours on each homework, probably more on the Poker assignment. 

Blaer is a very charismatic and enjoyable lecturer. However, if you are someone who doesn't know what is going on, it's easy to get confused because he incorporates jargon that we learned in class into his explanations. If you don't understand a previous concept, MAKE SURE you figure it out asap.

As someone who got an A and was incredibly confused half of the semester, my best advice is to 1) Start HW early and go to office hours for help. There are lots of TAs so I'd suggest going to different ones and figuring out which TAs you like; 2) Actually read the Zybooks and make sure you know how to do all of the problems. For greater understanding, do the challenge problems; 3) Go to the review sessions and study everything he says for the midterm/final. I found YouTube and previous lectures/HWs to be helpful. Final and midterm are similarly structured, and if you're confused start with memorizing the syntax of the algorithms he covers (binary search, linear search, max/min, selection/insertion sort).

I took ESP and that was a super chill, surface-level introduction to CS concepts.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 40% Homework, 10% Zybooks participation (only need to do 80% to get full credit), 20% Midterm, 30% Final. The raw average for my semester was an 82, and he curves the average to a low B+ and the median to an A-, so it is pretty fair.

reviews.content: Great Professor who understands Java inside and out. Even if you come with knowledge of programming already (which I did with python) you will still learn a lot and maybe fall in love with java. If you didn't you will be fine and you will learn a lot and maybe fall in love with programming. The most important thing I realized is to code along with Prof Blaer during his lectures. Just open a personal Codio Project and type with him as he codes on his computer. Coding > taking notes and you will do well on the exam. When it comes to exams Prof Blaer does half the work for you already. He lists out all that you need to know in a txt file. All you have to do is just reimplement (from your understanding/memory) what's on the list two days before the exam. Allow one day of sleep to commit to memory and you will get 90+ on exams. It worked for me and it may work for you but everyone has their own study methods! Have fun!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Extremely fair grading. Hours depend on how comfortable you are with the material.

reviews.content:
Overall positive experience. Professor Blaer is a very kind person. He is the most understanding professor of all the professors I have taken class with. He truly tries his best to adjust the release date and homework deadline to make our lives easier because he understands we have a lot of work to do.
He and the TAs are also very supportive, super quick in responding questions on ed.

I have to however agree with other comments that I don't love his teaching style. He is not bad at explaining concepts, but there are no slides or complementary notes for most coding lectures and therefore the learning process feels unstructured. The strategy is to make your own notes with the recordings after class, because it's hard to make a structured notes in class when you don't know where he's going. I however did not realize this early on and did not make my own notes. So although I ended up an A I feel like I did not have a clear picture of what I have learned.
It's a bit ironic because the logistics stuff in this class are pretty structured and organized in my opinion.

I personally did not encounter any difficulties in seeking support, so I disagree with other comments saying he is unapproachable.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
10 homework assignments (40%), weekly Zybook exercises (10%), a midterm exam (20%), and a final exam (30%)
Zybook is basically reading assignments with coding exercises.

Average, maybe a bit heavier workload if you have no coding experience.

Grading is fair. The written responses for both homework and exams, however, are strict in a way that you have to answer exactly what they are expecting. I got points deducted because the response not 100% the same with the rubric, although I already show clear understanding to the question.

reviews.content: I dislike Blaer’s teaching style. All he does is talk through code that is explained in Zybooks anyway. He gets frustrated at students for asking questions when he is the one that can’t understand their questions. Lots of the problems on the midterm/final are so semantic and I feel like a lot of them don’t properly test your ability to program. His TA’s are mostly awful, most of them are useless and some don’t even show up to their office hours. Would not recommend taking this intro class with Blaer, he moves too quickly for actual beginners and his attitude towards students is peeving, at best.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science in Java

reviews.workload: 10 assignments, alternating between programming and Zybooks problems, 1 hour max for written homework’s, 3 hours max for programming homeworks

reviews.content: I had previously taken APCSA before so I didn't find this class to be particularly challenging. However, I think it would be for someone who has no coding experience as it can be quite fast. Classes tend to consist of Professor Blaer coding something and talking through his process. Attendance is optional and all classes can be attended on zoom, in-person, or watched at a later time (lectures are recorded). Professor Blaer is very funny and relaxed.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: There are 10 homework assignments and additional practice problems and readings (about 10 total). Some of the homeworks take longer than others (anywhere from 20 min to 6 hours) and overall I would say the workload is fair. Practice problems and readings often took me about an hour. The TAs grading can be a little harsh and inconsistent because there are about 20 TAs.

reviews.content: Dr Paul Blaer is a terrible professor. His lecture isn't worth going to because he talks about himself half of the time. He frequently changes his schedule to compensate for his poor lifestyle decisions and expects students to adjust to it. He's existed at Columbia as a professor because he clueless with fundamentals such as JSON which are heavily used in the profession and would never last in corporate. His TAs take off points for no reason then they make you fill out a "regrade request form" to fix their grading error and never entertain it. Its amazing that a university such as Columbia employs him when they have so many better options. Dr Blaer is unable to uphold any standards and grades out of his own complacency. Such a waste of time & money.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: He fails to make assignments live on time. I've had points deduced from several correct answers and the TAs act like its your problem when you confront them about it.

reviews.content: Professor Blaer is an amazing lecturer and does a good job of keeping the class interesting. He's generally very organized when it comes to the material he's covering and was not unfair about grading or what should be expected for each assignment. His office hours are very brief though and he can come off as unfriendly during them, so I would only recommend attending them if you really need help that only he can provide (otherwise his TA's should be enough). If you have an ounce of coding background this class is fairly light; just pay attention to the lectures and you'll be fine. If you're completely new, I would recommend watching Java videos to supplement the lecture/textbook material since I've heard it can be quite confusing on its own.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: There were some coding assignments that weren't terribly hard and some written assignments that were a bit strict with how they were graded. I would 100% say though that if you study well enough and pay attention none of the assignments or exams are too difficult.

reviews.content: I had some background in Java so this class wasn't too difficult for me but it was to others. Blaer is an overall nice professor, however beware that there is not much "teaching" in class, more-so practice of textbook concepts.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Assignments were not overly difficult and were graded fairly. Maybe spent 1 hour most times on assignments, up to 2-3 hours on the more difficult ones, but again did have some experience in Java.

reviews.content: Was absolutely terrified going in given my little experience in the subject but Professor Blaer explained the content very well, he’s a super kind professor and also pretty funny. First few days is just teaching the basic definitions and ideas but then we went straight into coding, the coding in class would relate to our homework as well. Was absolutely horrified at my midterm grade but the final really saved my butt, there’s also an overall curve on your grade at the end of the semester so don’t be scared if you failed a HW or the midterm. Content mostly covered the basics of Java like operators, arrays, importing Java resources, command line arguments, Boolean, recursion, etc.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: If I remember correctly, there were 10 assignments, half were coding and the others were written (theory and such). There is one midterm worth 20%, HW is worth 50% and final is 30%, I did spend a lot of time on the HW probably 10-12 hours on the worst one but it was doable. Professor Blaer’s grading is fair, TA hours are SUPER HELPFUL, got a B+ in this class and I’m content with that :).

reviews.content:
I'd like to start off this review by saying that I already knew how to code in JavaScript, so things like if statements, while loops, etc. was just a review. When it came to things that were knew to me, though, it took a long time to learn them and grasp a basic understanding of each concept. I can't even begin to imagine what this course would have been like for someone who knew absolutely no code. (If you have time, I would recommend watching intro to Java videos on YouTube to get preliminary exposure to the content!) The assignments were hard, I'm not gonna lie. Especially the programming ones. For the biggest assignments I probably spent close to 15 hours/week on them, and still wasn't able to get a perfect score. When it comes to TA's, you just have to find the good ones. Some of them simply don't show up or don't know what they are doing, and some of them are better then Blaer tbh. Also, ALWAYS REQUEST REGRADES!!! I can't even count the amount of times TA's messed up my grade, even on the Midterm. When in doubt, just send a regrade request. 

Blaer is a fun prof. He tells fun stories and will go over concepts again for better understanding. Sometimes he glosses over things that are actually important though, so I would recommend re-watching parts of lectures closer to the exams to make you studied everything.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 assignments (5 theoretical/written, 5 programming), and the lowest score from each category is dropped. 1 midterm and 1 final. HWs are 50% of the grade, though, so focus on those. He also curves the class at the end, so it makes up for the harsh grading. The programming assignments take a long time, so start them early and go to TA's when you need help.

reviews.content: Professor Blaer is super funny and he is active on Reddit, commented on my post about him which caught me as a surprise. His class is never boring and he always makes time to answer any questions any students have. He does Zoom meetings for all his lectures and uploads them on Canvas. As a student with 0 prior experience in programming, his lectures are easy enough to follow and he explains the concepts very thoroughly. I would like to take Data Structures in Java class with him as well but unfortunately, he has taken sabbaticals. I would highly recommend taking his classes if you can.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 homeworks (5 written and 5 coding) with lowest odd numbered and even numbered homework dropped. HW - 50%, Midterm - 20% and Final - 30%. He had review sessions before both exams where he basically tells us what will be on the exam but the actual exams had a little twists here and there. Generously curved up the final grade which I got B from C grade.

reviews.content: I had Blaer for 1004 and really enjoyed it, but Data Structures was definitely a step up in terms of both difficulty of understanding and workload. I liked Blaer's teaching and thought he explained concepts very well, but at times I felt the class was too conceptual/theoretical and since Blaer does not write out his notes (so you just have to take notes of him while he is speaking), I found it was difficult to synthesize the information and retain it after class was over. The homeworks were difficult but the TAs were helpful so going to OH helped a lot.
reviews.workload: 10 assignments in pairs (5 written, 5 coding). They are assigned in pairs and have around 2 weeks for each pair. Almost all of them are quite difficult and each pair would probably take between 5-15 hours (at least for me including OH). 1 was dropped at the end for us. The midterm and final had both coding questions and theoretical questions and Blaer is very good at telling you the types of questions that will be on it. However, there is still a lot of content to study.

reviews.content: This is not an introductory class at all. This man expects you to already know most things. He doesn't go over most concepts as they are "too trivial" and you will end up very lost on the homework assignments. It is possible to get very high grades in this class- I was completely new to programming and wasn't even intending to be a CS major so I had a VERY hard time adjusting to his lecture style and the concepts. But I had to study a disgusting amount of time just to understand the lectures. The midterm is mostly handwriting code and even though he "tells you every question on the exam," that review session is like two days before the exam and probably won't help much if you're a normal student with problem sets and other exams to study for. He also teaches new concepts that are on the exam literally the last lecture before the exam date, so nothing even marinates in time for you to apply what you learned on the exam. If you don't have prior experience in CS, you should prolly take it with a diff professor because you won't actually LEARN anything, it'll just be you trying to survive the assignments and exams.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Grading is very fair and probably the most lenient out of all the other professors.

reviews.content: Before getting into this class, other CS majors said that DS would be easy. For me, it was a little harder than Intro to Java with Blaer. There is a lot of more content to understand and fit in. Blaer does a good job of going through and explaining the overall general concepts of DS but I found him to digress into off topic subjects this semester, which made the learning tougher for me. I did not enjoy how he taught us how to code using DS algorithms by just perusing through the textbook code. It would have been nice if had done live coding of DS algorithms in example coding like he did in Intro to Java, because when it came to completing the homeworks, I understood the concepts but barely know how to code such concepts from scratch. His grading policy is very consistent, which I appreciate. The midterm was more difficult than what I expected. Even though he said what was going to be on the midterm, I found the questions to be more complex than I thought. There were a lot of tree questions, even though he had taught it the week prior without giving us time to absorb how trees work through homework. I like the class' consistency in written and coding assignments.
reviews.workload: 5 written and 5 coding assignments (50%), midterm (20%), final (30%)

reviews.content: I had Blaer for intro java as well and really enjoyed his teaching, which is why I wanted him for data structures. I loved how all the classes were recorded because it was really easy to catch up on missed material and review for tests. Also, his grading policy was very lenient. His mean tends to be a B+ and his median an A-. There are 8-10 homework assignments (half written, half coding), one midterm, and a final. You get two weeks to complete each homework assignment, and 8 late days.
reviews.workload: I probably spent 5-10 hours on each coding assignment and under 5 hours per written assignment.

reviews.content:
Went into this class with zero coding experience and the first few weeks were a huge learning curve. It seemed like everyone already knew the basics, but reading the textbook was a massive help. Blaer's a loud, funny guy who engages students effectively with entertaining lectures and mini tangents. Homeworks felt challenging at the time, but it's definitely because I waited until the last minute to start them. Assignment releases/TAs and grading were a bit disorganized sometimes, but it wasn't too horrible. 

Overall I'd take another class with Blaer, but I probably wouldn't take this class unless you need to fulfill a requirement, since it requires a lottt of effort if you don't have prior experience.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science in Java

reviews.workload: 10 hw assignments (50%) - half programming, half written - lowest grade for each type is dropped. Starting early is so so crucial, plus TA office hours tend to get packed closer to the deadline. Two exams -- one midterm (20%) and one final (30%). Go to the review sessions, he literally goes thru the exam questions!!!

reviews.content:
I highly recommend this class with Blaer. If you have the chance to take Java 1004 with him, do it. 

He is a very entertaining lecturer who shares fun stories while still effectively teaching all the material. 

I came in with no CS experience, and there was a bit of a learning curve, but this class made me want to be a CS major. I loved it so much. It was a good amount of work, especially the first semester, to just understand the syntax of everything. It was a lot like learning a new language. But once I got the hang of things it was fine. 

He does the lectures in person, but also streams them on zoom so you can watch online if you’d like. They’re also all recorded and posted to courseworks, so you can watch whenever you want and rewatch for review. That is super helpful. 

Only bad thing about this class is that even though there are a crazy amount of TA’s, it’s hard to have significant one on one time with a TA in office hours because they’re so crowded. You really have to come in with one specific question rather than just a general statement of confusion. It’s just a huge class and everyone wants help at office hours, so it’s hard to get much attention. 

Also we got our semester grade super late: January 18. That sucked. 

I also took Java Labs, which I would recommend for the grade boost and for having more time learning the material. 

tldr; great class! awesome professor who is both effective and entertaining. had no experience and made me want to be a cs major

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Workload was okay. Lots of work to understand in the beginning but got better. 10 homework assignments, and two were dropped.

reviews.content:
Disclaimer: After this class I became a computer science major. 

I feel this class was an effective and comprehensive introduction to programming. Blaer is an entertaining and passionate lecturer. I will say that Blaer will lie to you about how quickly you will get grades back. I will say that it is likely not the best introductory class for you if you are not planning to major or minor. 

This class can be intimidating. It is a massive lecture class. My section had ~400 students and the class overall had ~600. Most students also seem to have some programming experience. I came in with no programming experience and did find it intimidating. The difficulty of the homework assignments does increase rapidly. 

However, there is a fair grading breakdown and support available. 

I took this class in conjunction with Emerging Scholars Program and Java Labs. I greatly enjoyed both and found them to be low commitment but worthwhile. Would recommend Java Labs for anyone with no prior experience. ESP was a very interesting high-level overview of Computer Science fields.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
Intense but manageable.
Ten homework assignments, 5 programming, 5 written assignments distributed over the course of the semester. 150 late hours given, lowest homework grade dropped. One midterm and one final. Both curved, though the method of curving is opaque.

reviews.content: The course content mainly pertained to programming in Java rather than foundational concepts in computer science. While we did occasionally touch on topics like computer memory, these were very briefly presented in relation to a programming concept rather than as distinct topics to be familiar with. Professor Blaer is an excellent instructor in that he is firm, but fair. However, it's clear that he is spread thin and thus relies heavily on his TAs who made frequent grading errors and were often difficult to reach. There also appeared to be some grading variation (in that some TAs would grant or withhold points for given criteria while others wouldn't).

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
The course workload was intense, but manageable, with some weeks requiring substantially more effort than others. Two of the programming assignments (termed "the beast" and "baby beast") were very difficult, but really forced you to become a competent beginner Java programmer. I credit those two assignments with making many of the programming concepts I didn't understand come together in my mind.

The class was divided between those who had prior programming experience (mainly Python, though we did have some Java programmers as well) and those who didn't. It was my sense that those already familiar with a programming language had an easier time handling the workload that those who didn't.

reviews.content: Really great professor! Blaer is an entertaining, funny lecturer but also explains everything super well and takes the time to answer everyone's questions, no matter how basic, and is very patient. Lectures usually consisted of live coding with an occasional pen and paper to explain concepts. My only complaint would be 1. The TA office hours are always extremely busy, and 2. false promises for grading; when Blaer says to expect grades by a certain date, expect it 2 weeks later. Would really recommend this class!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Homework assignments are half written and half programming. Written ones are usually relatively straightforward, the latter programming ones can be very time consuming taking many hours over 1-2 weeks, but are worth it as they really help you understand the concepts and OOP in Java.

reviews.content:
Taken Spring 2021.

Humorous and engaging lecturer. Storytime tangents that give insight or are just funny.

Textbook: Mark Allen Weiss, Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis in Java, 3rd Edition, Pearson, 2012. ISBN: 9780132576277.

Topics Covered:
Recursion
Algorithm Analysis
Linked Lists
Stacks, Queues
Trees
Heaps
Sorting
Hashing
Graphs
NP-Completeness
Functional Programming

~JW CC'24
reviews.workload:
6 HWs, ~2 weeks each, 150 late hours (max 48/HW), lowest dropped (50%)
Midterm (20%)
Final (30%)

reviews.content: Prof. Blaer is kind and funny. He is a good person and has big positive energy. Downside? He is not a good lecturer. You will find yourself having to self-learn most if not all of the material. A lot of the people who do good in this class have had prior programming or java experience. If you are a complete beginner, you will struggle! There are TA sessions everyday and Blaer definitely tries his best to help and devote his time.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: Workload was manageable 10 hws (textbook and programming). There are textbook readings to fully understand the lectures but they are pretty long and boring.

reviews.content: I didn't know Hagrid's calendar moves at a different rate than us mortals. When Hagrid says he will upload homework or post your grades at a certain time, expect that to take maybe about ten times longer because us mortals' calendars somehow move at a faster speed than Hagrid's.

The review dated June 09, 2020 is probably the most accurate review of this class imo. In short: Blaer is a lovely, hilarious teddy bear that I want to befriend irl but he isn't the most outstanding Professor.
I think that Blaer can choose better TAs tbh. There are several TAs who are frequently arriving to their OHs late/ forgetting to attend their own OHs. Furthermore, some of them don't bother to refresh their memory on the current topics/homework. That being said, Bo is the most amazing TA I've ever met! He taught me to approach Blaer's data structures class in a more lighthearted manner. I will miss Bo after this semester!

The class content is not hard. Professor Paul tends to extend the homework due date when most students starting on it later than his expectation. That's great since we were supposed to have 6 homework sets and now we have 5.
The entire TAing system is a mess. When there are questions regarding clarification of the homework problems, TAs may give inconsistent answers. So the best thing to do is post the clarification question on Piazza directly.
Homework problems are related to his lecture closely. And he sometimes will talk through the structure of some coding homework problems during class which is helpful.
Exams are similar to homework but much easier.

This class is a hot mess. I don’t know if it is because it’s online or just his teaching style but the lectures are super confusing. It seems that he just talks and talks and expects the information to naturally stick. Even worse, the textbook makes no sense and is very dense. Being the only DS class offered this semester I had to take it, but definitely one of the most confusing classes I have taken so far.

Prof. Blaer is my favorite professor at Columbia and I loved taking Data Structures with him! His lectures always target the key points, and he’ll occasionally throw in a relevant joke or story. He’s also accommodating and receptive to feedback, and the curve is generous. Even if you aren’t pursuing a CS degree, I highly recommend taking Data Structures with him if you enjoyed 1004.
My only complaint is that the Weiss textbook is subpar and should not be your primary resource in this class. The book is dense and reads more like an academic paper; it’s clogged with esoteric proofs and errors. Use Weiss for its source code, but refer to Cracking the Coding Interview, YouTube videos (I recommend the Back To Back SWE channel), and sites like GeeksforGeeks for mastering the concepts.

The good: Blaer is nice, funny, approachable, and the curve is generous. The hw sets are also reasonable.

The bad: Blaer is not a good lecturer. The currciuculum glosses over a lot of topics. The motivation behind the data structures are not explained. Honestly, data structures at Columbia is a joke. For a class that is very important to computer science, you will feel like you can do the problem sets and maybe get As, but will end the class thinking that you did not learn anything. Connections between the data structures are not explained. A lot of times I had knowledge of the topic behind explained, but sat there and saw him explain it for the first time and thought that if this was my first time being exposed to what he is saying, I wouldn't have grasped the material. Honestly, a very frustrating experience. Also the book is terrible; the code is filled with a lot bugs. Skip class and learn the material on your own. Also use problems sets from other universities to actually learn data structures. If you are doing the problem sets being assigned and think they are easy, that is because you are not learning actual data structures, just a bunch of disconnected programs. The theory part is better than the programming though. The course lacks the depth needed for cs.
reviews.workload: Reasonable.

reviews.content:
Hagrid is a clear, knowledgeable, kind, and helpful professor. I admit the class felt a little easy because of how slow he went; I ended up not paying attention to most lectures and instead relied on the very excellent textbook by Weiss to get me through. The homeworks and tests were quite easy and fair.

It's not a breeze though. You need to put in the time to understand these occasionally complex algorithms, and develop an intuition for them. If you know the basics of Java, the programming is a breeze. The written homeworks (i.e. exercises from the textbook) were occasionally difficult, but never completely stumped me. I never used them, but I've heard office hours and TAs are genuinely incredible.
reviews.workload:
One written and one programming homework every two weeks-ish
One midterm
One final

reviews.content:
Blaer is a nice guy who is not a great teacher. As a professor of a large lecture class, those two qualities are heightened: his jokes (though repetitive) can be stress-relieving, and if you have a background in java, his explanations are intriguing. However, if you don't have a background in java, Blaer is not very good at explaining simple concepts. He over-explains, confuses students, and gets distracted easily. I personally felt that my time was better spent on learning java online than learning in his class.

One specific moment that comes to mind is Blaer's introduction to stacks. He went on an hour-long description of the intricacies of a stack, over-explaining it, when in all honesty it's a somewhat-simple java topic. All he really needed to say was "this is like a list, but instead of being able to access any node at any time, stacks follow the process of last-in first-out, like a tissue box or a pile of books."

To be fair to Blaer, he is an incredibly nice professor who has the difficult job of teaching nearly 450 students in one large lecture class. I'm not sure anyone would have been able to do as good a job as online learning, especially in a class on Computer Science. 

My advice: take his class, but don't expect it to be great. Enjoy the comedic, positive side of Blaer, and deal with the negative sides of the class by learning online or reading the textbook.
reviews.workload:
- 6 written HWs (25%). + 6 programming HWs (25%) **He lets you drop your lowest written/programming hw grade
- Midterm (20%)
- Final (30%)

reviews.content:
If you have a decent amount of experience programming, this class will probably be a breeze but pay attention to the minutia of how Java works and especially to the hardware and theory lectures.
If you've never programmed before, this is the class to start with. It might be rough, but pay attention and practice and you will succeed. There will be a temptation to slack off during lectures because you will have your laptop open and sometimes the content can seem a little slow. Do not do this.
Paul Blaer is a lovely, hilarious, clear, concise, friendly, loud guy and an incredible teacher.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science in Java

reviews.workload:
About 10 homework assignments. Half programming, half written problems from the textbook. Programming homeworks significantly harder than written, both scored on accuracy and grading can be a little pedantic depending on your TA but you can also request a regrade quite easily.
One midterm and a final.

reviews.content:
LOVE Paul Blaer!! Hands down my favorite Professor at Columbia so far. He is such a good teacher & amazing at explaining concepts. He is also incredibly nice & just a really genuine, down to earth person. 

As for the class itself: I loved it as well & was definitely one of my favorite classes at Columbia so far. I had actually not done any programming in Java for a few years, because I had taken AP CS in high school & skipped 1004, so it took me a bit of time to adjust and remember/relearn some things. The class was definitely challenging, but not too much and in a good way I think. I really learned a lot from the class & fell in love with CS again (I wasn't a CS major going into the class, but I am now). 

The TAs were also super super helpful & I highly recommend going to office hours to work on the assignments/study for tests (it's so much harder on your own trust me), and there are so many TAs so there are office hours like literally all the time which is so nice. 

This class is required for the CS major & minor, but I'd honestly recommend taking it even if you aren't majoring/minoring in CS. I would also highly recommend taking it when Blaer is teaching,if possible (he's like 1000x better than the other profs who teach it).
reviews.workload:
Homework: ~every 2 weeks. Had a coding component & written component. Most are not too bad & the first couple are pretty easy. A lot are pretty complicated & take some time, so I highly recommend going to office hours. Blaer said back when he took the class they took him ~24+ hours each to complete & I think that's pretty accurate.

Exams: Midterm (moderately difficult, but curved a lot), and final (pretty similar to midterm). They're kinda similar to the homeworks & blaer gives lots of hints to questions in class ;)

reviews.content: A witty, intelligent, and entertaining professor. He talks a bit fast at times but is always willing to repeat what he said if you ask. Assignments aren't too difficult but might take some time if you're 100% new to CS. If he hears people talking while he's lecturing he will ask what they are talking about or if a part of a song accidentally plays aloud he will ask what song it was – those moments definitely add some excitement to class. All in all a good teacher he seems to genuinely want to help his students succeed. Note: He gives out many A- but As are quite difficult to get.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science in Java

reviews.workload:
About one programming or writing assignment a week. --> a couple hours of work at most
1 midterm
1 final

reviews.content:
One of the best professors at Columbia hands down. The material is non-trivial but he makes it a breeze with great lectures and a generally well organized course. Blaer is also very approachable if you happen to have questions in office hours.

Many people will take this as a required course, but even for non-CS majors I'd highly recommend.
reviews.workload: Will be highly variable depending on your background, but if you are already comfortable with Java then none of the homeworks are that time consuming.

reviews.content: Blaer is one of the best professors I ever had (and probably will ever have)!!! He is a well-organized lecturer and delivers the material in a very clear and succinct way. After taking this class, I decide to pursue CS further - one of the best course I have taken and my favorite class. 20/10 recommend!
reviews.workload: A bit heavier since you have to do the readings to understand the material better

reviews.content:
By far the best professor I ever had. He speaks loudly and clear with a touch of wit. Most importantly, however, professor Blear knows how to explain the crap out of everything. I never walked out of his lecture asking myself, "What the hell was that?" 

He has a way of explaining the most difficult topics so a 5-year-old could understand.

Thank you, Professor Blear!
reviews.workload: 5 hw, mid term, and final

reviews.content: Great professor. As mentioned above, literally Hagrid. Has a booming voice that is easy to understand. Homework assignments are tough but fair. Exams are similar. Will not try to confuse you; go to class, read the book, and you'll be prepared for the exams.
reviews.workload: Medium-heavy to heavy.

reviews.content:
Literally hagrid. 
11/10 prof
reviews.workload: just about enough

reviews.content:
Prof. Blaer really reached out to me in a personal way to make both Intro to CS and Data Structures meaningful courses for me. Blaer is an expert in the field of computer science (also, has special interests in robotics programming), speaks [loudly and] clearly during lectures, has a dry but relatable sense of humor, and is generally an approachable friendly human.  

tl;dr I highly recommend Blaer for CS major courses: 'Introduction to CS in Java' and 'Data Structures in Java'.
reviews.workload: Don't expect it to be easy. Consider Blaer's courses as the main stakes underpinning the rest of your schedule (perhaps, along with one other mainstay/major course, e.g., Discrete Mathematics).

reviews.content:
A standard introductory data structures class. Professor Blaer is pretty good, although his proofs could be a little more rigorous. The class felt slow to me, but maybe it was the right speed for an introductory class. The "Honors" nature of this class consisted of learning a little bit of Ocaml, which was interesting.

My one complaint is the textbook: Weiss Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis in Java. It is a expensive and terrible book. Both the code and the proofs are lacking.

The homeworks were easy, easier than the ones in 1007. The exams were fine.
reviews.workload: 6 homeworks, lowest dropped. 2 exams.

reviews.content:
I came into this class having taken a basic programming course in high school.  It wasn't completely a breeze, but very doable and I came through with an A.  With such a basic CS course, there is a lot of information out there if you get lost, and you should utilize it.  The book is very useful, office hours are a big help, there are many resources online, and other students can be helpful with the homeworks if you don't know where to start.  Blaer is a great professor - entertaining, funny, and makes things very clear even when they're difficult concepts to grasp.  Having taken 1004 and 3134 with him, I'm sad to not have him as a professor next semester.

Make sure that you read the book and get help early if you think you might need it - the concepts you'll learn build on each other so it's important to not get lost or it will take a while to get back on track (same with all CS courses, IMO).  If you're new to CS, expect a struggle in the beginning since the most basic concepts are covered pretty quickly, but it will get easier for sure.

Get started on the homework as early as you can and things will go well!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 total homeworks (half programming and half written problems) which often took quite a few hours, midterm and final

reviews.content:
If you have no experience with Java, it's OK. The world is not going to end, but it won't be easy neither. I'm not a fan of reading but Big Java, Late Objects is one of the best books out there to learn Java. I gave my full attention to Blaer, but sometimes I would wonder off. But, it always came to taking some time to read the book and get the hang of it. Some of the answers of the Problem Sets are in the book itself. It's really important and useful that you read the book. Going to recitation doesn't make that much of a difference, unless you want to ask a question. And then again, they may even not answer them, but tell you to wait until Office Hours, since you're not the only one there. 

I had no experience with Java, got an A on the course. I am tech-savy, but it doesn't mean it's not achievable. Once you get the hang of it its pretty awesome! I do recommend taking the course with Paul. He is very funny and very lenient (we got our homework deadline extended like 3 times during the course). 

The problems sets are not that hard. Just make sure you take notes during class so that you can do your homework with them.
Not an "easy A", but its not impossible to get an A.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
11 Problem Sets - varied with just programming, some written, all written, etc. (1 was dropped)
1 Midterm - avg of 106/150 so great curve
Final

reviews.content:
tl;dr: This isn't a easy class if you have no compsci experience. However, if you insist on learning Java, Blaer's the best class to take. Problem sets are a bit of a struggle, exams are reasonable.

Blaer's a fun guy. He's down-to-earth and isn't pretentious. Expect a lot of tangential stories though. There are a lot of TAs, and they're for the most part helpful. Recitation is usually staged more of an OH though, they take questions & don't really have a set plan. You must go to the first recitation--that's when they go through how to set up pico so you can actually code, and it's a million times easier seeing them do it in front of you than trying to read the tutorial.

If you're like me and go into the class w/o knowing any compsci, you're going to spend the first few classes going "what the FUCK is going on." Be good about reviewing notes and reading the textbook though (and doing a lot of googling), and eventually you'll catch up.

Before each exam he'll usually go over what will be tested. Make sure to go to at least one of the TA's review sessions--they'll usually cover something a little more comprehensively than Blaer. Exams are decent. Often I just read & reread the textbook and that was enough. The final covered way more content, but to make up for it it was also easier. 

Also, use Piazza religiously. Questions are almost immediately answered and any question you might have will probably already be up there.

An A is definitely doable, no matter your past experience; you're going to have to put in some work & effort though.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload:
10 problem sets, half written/half programming. Takes some time.
Midterm 
Final

reviews.content:
If you have previous experience in coding, you most likely will not have trouble with this class. If this is your very first exposure to computer science, be forewarned that this is a challenging class. It will be much more rigorous than most likely any other introductory course in other fields. That being said, if you put in the effort, this class is very doable. You will be spending hours studying, as it requires learning both a language (java) and a general science (CS theory). If you do you not intend to be a computer science major, I would suggest taking a different course that involves coding (like a applications course that teaches Python with another subject, or a coding course for nonmajors). If you do take this course, be prepared to do a lot of googling & research on your own to figure out how Java works. It would really help you to do some basic tutorials to get the gist of it before you head into the first lecture. 

Blaer is an excellent professor, and his explanatory style is very clear and concise. He gets very distracted in his lectures, and it's pretty hilarious and adorable--which always made them a pleasure to attend. His expectations for tests and homeworks are always very clear. He does, however, have a tendency to underemphasize how difficult/important topics will be. For example, when listing topics to go over on test, if he mentions something in passing, you should know it pretty much backwards and forwards. Another example, the second to last homework we used a hashmaps, FileReaders, and PrinterWriters--all of which he probably talked about for like two seconds and never explained. 

Additionally, the TAs are beautiful, wonderful human beings. James Lin the head TA/(and I quote) "aspiring Little League Coach" is the best thing to happen to 1004 probably ever, and he was very encouraging and generally super kind in all his emails and communications. They are all very helpful, just be sure to find one who you get along with and remember their office hours (there are like a 11 TAs, and like always office hours). Piazza is also a great resource, with under 15 min response times. Usually all of my questions were already answered there before I even needed to ask anyone.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 10 total homeworks, half programming and half written problems (basically one a week). Both are challenging, although the relatively diffictulty from one assignment to the next varies greatly. Allow yourself the time to fully explore them. Recitations are largely unnecessary/extra. One midterm, one final.

reviews.content:
Definitely take this class. Blaer is incredible and hilarious. You don't really need to go to the lectures to understand this, especially because the book does a great job of explaining it but its good to go just to hear Blaer talk. The class is not too difficult and is a great introduction to Java, very interesting and I learned a lot. If you are on the fence about it you should for sure take the class.

The homework assignments can be challenging sometimes but he gives you a ton of time to do them and there are so many TA's for this class that it makes everything very doable.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in Java

reviews.workload: 1 midterm 1 final ~9 homework assignments

reviews.content:
Professor Blaer is a great instructor. He is clear, able to command a large lecture hall without much trouble, and able to explain concepts in a fairly simple manner. I honestly don't understand why some people chose not to attend this class because I found the book to be average at explaining concepts, while I found Professor Blaer to be exceptional at explaining the material. I rarely referred to the book after his lectures because I either understood the material from his lecture, or was able to understand is after digesting my notes. I think this is a sign of a great teacher. 

Even in a 200+ person class, Blaer was able to captivate the room with his large voice and abundant personality. In addition, he managed to encourage student participation, which kept the class interactive and engaging. In addition, occasionally, Professor Blaer would drive home the importance of a particular concept with a story about his research, which usually involved a hilarious and catastrophic ending involving multi-ton robots ramming into buildings or almost running people over. 

Professor Blaer's exams are fairly straightforward and he essentially tells you about 50% of the exam, so these are fairly low stress endeavors. I found the final harder than the midterm, but still fairly straightforward. Not much to worry about here. 

My only complaint with Professor Blaer is an organizational complaint. He would usually claim he would post the HW by a certain date and note post it till 3 or 4 days afterwards. He also granted classwide extensions in unecesarry situations which made the last HW assigned and due during reading week, which was poor planning on his part. Lastly, I feel that the first 15 minutes of class, where students as clarification questions on the HW, is a waste of time. If he wrote his questions in a less ambiguous manner, and used this class time to teach more material, that would be more efficient. Apart from those organization things, I can't complain about this professor. I would recommend his class to anyone in a heartbeat.
reviews.workload:
6 HW Assignments, top 5 counted. (50%)
Midterm Exam (20%)
Final Exam (30%)

reviews.content:
Paul Blaer is an excellent professor. His lectures are generally very clear and straightforward. Don't hesitate to ask questions if you don't understand something, since he is very good at answering questions both in-class and through emails. Occasionally he'll tell a few stories about his research. Overall, a cool and funny guy who definitely deserves the nugget.

The learning curve might be a bit steep in the beginning (it wasn't too bad for me, but some of my peers thought it was), but once you can get over that initial hump everything works itself out. Just be sure to start early on the programming assignments or you will have a terrible time (no joke). In contrast to the 1004 TAs, it seemed that the 3134 TAs were more lenient on the style of the code - if the code works, you get a 100% regardless of how ugly your code looks.

TL;DR Excellent class. If you put in the work and pay attention in class, you will do well.

Reviewer's grade: A
reviews.workload:
Homework: 50%
Combination of both written exercises from Weiss's Data Structures in Java and programming projects. DO NOT PROCRASTINATE! Due every 2-2.5 weeks. Total of about 5-6 homework assignments (there were six this semester, but he only took the top 5 scores - the last was somewhat optional)

Midterm: 20%
Unlike the multiple-choice exams in 1004, the exams either require you to write a short answer, pseudocode, a short Java method, or walk through an algorithm (e.g. Dijkstra's) step-by-step. If you pay attention in class and study your notes/book, there should be no surprises.

Final: 30%
Similar to midterm, except longer.

reviews.content:
Took course over the summer. Very solid instructor, lectures were clear. Managed to make 3 hours of lecture bearable. Assignments really helped understand the material and were time-consuming, challenging, but not unmanageable. The reviews below apply.

Why am I reviewing then, if what I've said above has already been said before? If you are taking THE SUMMER COURSE, expect to receive your final grade VERY LATE compared to the usual standards. Class ended in mid-August, and I received my grade early September, about 3-4 weeks after the end of the course. 

When I took Intro to MATlab with him during the year a long time ago, grading timeliness was never an issue at all, so I'm not sure where the disconnect lies.
reviews.workload: See reviews below.

reviews.content:
One of the best and most helpful professors I've ever had. His class is not easy, but if you can get through his class you'll make it through cs. He presents the material clearly. Keeps the class engaged with humor while not coming across as a goofball. 

Do the assignments, don't expect perfection and read the text. Start early you won't finish projects if you start the night before. Recursion, writing compression and encryption algorithms, red/black trees, definitely a gateway to the more heavy duty programming classes. Much harder than the intro to cs classes. If you tap out of cs this is where you'll probably do it. But you shouldn't Prof. Blaer is very helpful. It might not necessarily lead to a high-flying gpa but its a great class to put on the books.
reviews.workload: heavy

reviews.content:
Best professor I've run into at Columbia so far. 

About me: Took AP Comp Sci in High School, had Art of Engineering the previous semester so I knew some rudimentary Matlab. 

I found his lectures really clear and if you take good notes you shouldn't find anything a surprise in the midterm or final. Also he uploads the things he ran in Matlab at the end of lecture so you see what you kinda covered during the lecture. Definitely go to class. 

No textbook required: i managed without it. You can also find a lot of the things on the Matlab website. 

Workload: He has 6 problem sets and drops one. You should not wait until the day before its due because some will take a bit of time. Start early and do a little each day and workload isn't bad at all. Also, he often extends the due date for things which is always a plus for you procrastinators but don't try to rely on that. 

Exams: He reviews what will be on it and reviews the exam after. 

Exams go for "breadth rather than depth." Exams weren't too difficult at all. You shouldn't have an awful time. He's also quite friendly and approachable. I found he answers emails in an appropriate amount of time. 

Overall I recommend this professor!

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in MATLAB

reviews.workload:
6 Problem sets (1 dropped)
1 Midterm
1 Final
Overall not too bad at all. Completely do-able.

reviews.content:
I took this class having little prior programming experience, having only learned a bit of MATLAB in Art of Engineering. For SEAS and particularly BME students who are required to take this class, having the background in MATLAB from AoE is pretty useful and allows you to slide through the first couple of weeks easily. However, as the class progresses you start discussing Big O notation, structs, object oriented programming, functions like varargin and varargout, and recursion, which were not mentioned in AoE but are really useful to know and require some more time. Later in the course when Blaer talks about histogramming images, you can again use some of the code you wrote in AoE in the homework for this class. Anyway, Blaer is a great professor. He's easily approachable immediately after class or in his office hours. Blaer holds review sessions before the midterm and final, which are really helpful. He tells you what he's going to test over, explains challenging concepts, and in some cases tells you the exact questions. The best advice I can give is to go to class, because Blaer's teaching really clarifies the concepts asked about in the homework. Often you will be able to modify code he wrote in class to solve homework problems. Furthermore, nobody usually goes to TA office hours, but they're really helpful if you're having trouble with a particular problem on the homework, even if you have to go to the crowded Comp. Sci. lounge to utilize them. 

Other notes:
*You don't need the textbook for this class. Just take good class notes or get them from someone else. Blaer also posts all the code he writes on his website. 
*Also, you don't need any calculus for this course, but any coding experience will help.
*Just go to class. It makes everything easier... Blaer always asks if people have questions at the beginning of class.
*Blaer also tells funny stories about things like cat whiskers and building robots, another reason to attend class.

course_header.course_name: Intro to Computer Science- Programming in MATLAB

reviews.workload:
5 homeworks, each about 2 weeks to do, 6th homework is extra credit (a one question assignment involving GUIS). The first homework is super easy, average is 100. HW 3 and 4 are pretty hard, certain problems can take you a few hours to solve. Nothing too serious though.
1 midterm that's after spring break. Pretty hard, 150 points, 90 is curved to B+, ~120 for an A.
1 final, easier than midterm, 250 points.
I got an A without too much stress, and you can too.

reviews.content:
I'm optimistically assuming that the computer science department has the sense to never let Professor Blaer teach this class again, in which case this review doesn't really serve much of a purpose.  However, given the finite probability that computer science continues to show the lack of judgment that they showed in allowing him to teach COMS 1007 this past summer, I feel justified in writing this review.

I just got reminded this morning that I took COMS 1007 with Professor Blaer this past summer when I got an email that my grade arrived.  The date of the final exam was Thursday August 9th.  I had been checking Courseworks weekly since the end of the course, and this is the first time that I saw the grades posted for assignments 3-4.  I am currently enrolled in COMS 3137 and have completed the first two assignments prior to receiving my grades for the last two assignments and my final grade from COMS 1007.  There is still no grade posted on Courseworks for the final exam, and given that combined with the discrepancy between how well I did in the course and how poorly I felt I did on the final, I'm wondering if he even graded and/or counted the final exam.  This might sound like an outlandish accusation, but the classmates who I've talked to are  all speculating the same idea.  

Professor Blaer told us during the final lecture, on Tuesday August 7th, that he was setting the following Monday as the grading deadline for the TAs, and therefore that we should expect to know our final grades by the Tuesday of that week.  We were never contacted with notification of any delay.  At first I thought it was just me when my grade wasn't posted all summer, but then I got to COMS 3137 and found that several of my classmates who were in the summer class had not received their grades either, and we all had contacted him several times via email, telephone, and direct office visits.  Professor Blaer didn't respond to most of the emails or telephone calls, and he wasn't in his office when most people arrived.  However, whenever one of us did hear from him, he said that the grades would be up "by the end of the day."  

The lack of feedback and organization in this class was representative of the fact that the concern for students' learning was absent, which is a shame.  After all, isn't that the point of any class?  Professor Blaer's lectures were fine.  They weren't amazing, but they were fine.  However, in teaching a class in computer science, organization and feedback are at least as important as the lectures.
