The material is already difficult, and these problems build on that with an extremely crazy level of complexity. 2 hours of lecture a week, maybe 15-20 hours per homework at a MINIMUM.

reviews.content:
Would recommend, but not for the faint of heart. Perhaps the most difficult class in the cs department. I took this during covid so I had the time to devote to this class to get a decent grade but under normal circumstances this class would probably kill your social life. Gives you good fundamentals to attack deep learning, although arguably a lot of the content is useless for that if that’s what you want to get into. Also for the class competition everyone uses dl techniques so be prepared for that. The homework is hard but very doable if you have the ma background, you just have to understand what the problem is asking. Verma is a good lecturer but not very approachable imo.
This class requires high skill in math and programming. If you don’t have that, reconsider. If you do, get ready to lose your social life, although if you are good at math and programming you probably didn’t have one to begin with.

Overall, I wouldn’t recommend unless you have a deep math and stats background. Prof Verma is a great lecturer and explains concepts very clearly. However, the exams and homeworks are so incredibly difficult and way beyond the scope of what is covered in lecture. The homeworks take exorbitant amounts of time and are nearly impossible to complete without attending office hours regularly.

I came from a stats background with a CS background, so I don't think this course's difficulty for me resulted from a lack of preparation. 
That said, I found the difficulty of this class to often be absurd, and that's coming from a student with above a 4.0. The problem sets are interesting but I found them to be so difficult that doing well on them was mostly a matter of having time to go to office hours for the solutions. Moreover, they are extremely time consuming, and I would argue excessively so for a 3 credit class.
The midterm was not too bad, but Verma corrected that mistake with the final which was quite literally the hardest exam I've ever taken in my life. With that said, the class is curved so on net I guess that doesn't matter much. 
To end on a good note, lectures are good and I feel I learned a lot, even with some prior background in ML. Verma is a very good instructor when it comes to lecturing and explaining proofs and concepts. The only knock I have on the lecture component of the class is that we didn't get to HMMs which were the part of the class I was most looking forward to.

Do not expect any empathy or understanding from Prof. Verma if you make even a small mistake--I got a 0 on a homework worth 10% of my final grade because I misread something and tried to turn it in literally 10 minutes late. The homeworks take forever to do, and the exams are pretty challenging. That being said, he is a good lecturer. However, it is not very applied--we go through a lot of proofs of random things, and code algorithms from scratch, so if you're looking for that do not take this class.

I definitely recommend taking Machine Learning with Nakul Verma if you have knowledge of linear algebra and (to a lesser extent) statistics. To begin with, he is a clear and organized (and kind of funny!) lecturer, his course content is presented in an order that is logical and builds on itself. His lectures are paced well and doesn't try to cover too much content. If you are a person that has difficulty following along in lectures, the lectures are recorded and the slides are on his course website. Professor Verma is usually good about repeating inaudible questions from the class before answering them too. 

The content is a mix of theory/application, which he mentions early on. He goes through major proofs for ML theorems, but is pretty reasonable about what is in the scope of the class and as a result the math doesn't get too crazy or super irrelevant. 

The class had no required textbook which is financial plus - and the reading cited on his website were clear supplements that don't go over your head. 

I really recommend making sure you have an okay foundation in linear algebra, maybe prob stats as well. You don't need to be fresh off getting an A in lin alg, but the workload is heavy enough that if you are already taking a full course/research load, it may be difficult to find time to both catch up on the prereq knowledge and also submit thoroughly completed problem sets. He made a couple of jokes about putting test questions that dealt with certain distributions on them, but really all we needed for the class was an understanding of the Gaussian and binomial/Bernoulli distribution.

Overall, I felt like the class was a great introduction to machine learning, and sets up a foundation for future study well.
reviews.workload:
Moderately heavy. 

There are 5-6 problem sets, that were worth a total 40% of the grade. The first problem set did not count towards your class grade, it was weed out pset testing the preliminary linear algebra/stats knowledge. If you are concerned with whether you have background knowledge, this pset will let you know well before the drop deadline.

The next first four problem sets were time consuming - mitigated by the fact that you can work in groups of three. The questions themselves were not impossible, and any exceedingly difficult portions were quickly revised by the instructor/TA team to be "bonus" questions. He was reasonable giving out extensions. If you have team members and start early, they are doable. I would recommend starting early, especially as the code for one problem set took hours to converge - it's not something you'd want to start last minute. 

The last problem set (for the Spring 2019) semester, was individual and worth only 5%, but was assigned during finals week. The task was to make predictions based from real world data. 

All of the problem sets served to further understanding of the material, however because they were so long, you may not have time to adequately study the answers/practice with them for the exams. 

The midterm and final were each worth 30%. The class averages were around 35% and 40%, results are curved. If you treat them like exams in a math class, study the material but focus on working through practice problems, you will be fine. It helps during the exam itself if you are comfortable with linear algebra. They are open note exams.

reviews.content:
This is the best course that I have taken among all courses from my undergraduate and graduate schools. This course is epic. 

This course covers the foundation of machine learning. You will learn different machine learning algorithms from the foundation supported by math and proofs. 

I have weak mathematics before taking this class. My math background only has intermediate-level linear algebra, calculus, and intro-level probability. I haven't done math problems for three years.  Before taking this course, I also have completed Andrew Ng's online course. Before enrolling, I thought I might struggle in this class but, in fact, I survived well and really enjoyed my experience. 

First of all, this is not a relaxing course. It is challenging, but it is not a hard course! What I mean is that the course homework and tests are challenging, but this course is amazingly organized and Verma is an extremely capable instructor. Even though this is a challenging course, I feel safe and comfortable when I sit in the class even though with a weak math background because of Verma's teaching. Verma is very patient on teaching his topics and he cares about how his students learn with quality rather than quantity. He is a strict yet kind instructor. I could feel that he ardently cares about his class and his student. His teaching is perfect. I can understand everything that has been taught in his class even with my weak math background. The pace of the class is slow and nobody would feel lost.  

The homework are challenging but are interesting to solve. If you spend time on them you can always find solutions. TAs are also helpful in Piazza and OH. The tests are also challenging. However, grades are generously scaled and you might get A- if you get 60% in tests. 

I learned so many things from this course and it helped me build a fundamental understanding of machine learning problems. If you really want to work in ML-related careers or research, this is the recommended intro-level course. If you hesitate whether this course is too hard, I would say be brave and enroll. You will be fine (suppose you can get 70% right for the homework 0, which is the precondition of enrolling in this class . 70% is not a hard target). 

Columbia University's tuition fees are expensive. You want to spend your money in the right place, this is the course you should take
reviews.workload: Heavy but acceptable.

reviews.content:
I like Professor Verma so much that I decided to write a review: note that I'm biased.

Prerequisite: usually linear algebra and prob-stats. But I personally wished I learned more math, especially optimization related math. Although without those it will also be fine, with those knowledge you'll definitely get more out of the class. 

Homework: up to three students in a group, usually due 2~3 weeks after being posted. Try to pick your teammates cautiously, because if you don't, you'll be the one doing most of the work, which means a lot of hours into homework. I usually go to at least 6 hours of OH every week and read/post on Piazza to figure out the homework. But the homework problems are all interesting! And Professor and TAs are very helpful and responsive both in person and on Piazza. Fortunately, we only had four graded problem sets and the last one is optional. And no homework was due during spring break, which is nice.

Exams: Professor Verma made clear that usually you can pick some questions to finish; this is true. Due to the time constraint of 75~80 minutes, and there are 6 problems in total, I usually can only finish 4~5 problems and not all of what I wrote would be correct. But there's curve, so don't sweat too much. It's supposed to be hard!

This class teaches various topics on machine learning and I feel I actually know stuff about ML now. One thing I found helpful is that all the additional notes he linked on his website for each topic covered are very helpful. After lectures, sometimes I still have questions about the topics; if I read those notes, most of my questions get resolved. Make good use of them! 

Go to his OH and you'll learn a lot too! He is very approachable. 
TAs' recitations are also helpful. 

He's teaching a topics class on unsupervised learning next semester (during the summer too). Take his class if you can.
reviews.workload:
Pretty heavy. Comparable to Analysis of Algorithms. 

5 homework, 4 graded, 1 optional.
2 in-class exams. 

Homework 40%
Exam 30% each

reviews.content:
Prof Verma's Machine Learning class is a confusing mixture of being not technical enough and over-technical at the same time. He assumes knowledge of some advanced multivariate calculus, multivariate probability and linear algebra without going through the techniques explicitly or in any systematic way, while the prerequisite classes cover nothing close to what he requires. This could be partly due to the fact that half the class are grad students, with the overall result that undergrads feel very left behind. At the same time, Prof Verma introduces results of some advanced derivations, skipping over the math in class entirely with the reason that "it is too easy/simple/boring", but expects you to reproduce it in a test. He focuses on teaching the "intuition" behind the proofs, yet fails to understand that "intuition" comes from understanding, which is impossible for most students unless he goes more into the math. 

Another huge blindspot for the course is that Prof Verma does not give out solutions for his practice exams. This could seem forgivable, except the homework questions are nothing like exam questions (problem sets are more like mini-projects while exam questions are just out of nowhere), so students who have seen questions of this type for the first time are forced to study without any guide or solution. This coupled with reasons mentioned in the above paragraph result in overall confusion before the exams. (In addition, no one does well on the actual exams). The lack of solutions handed out caused some Piazza savagery in my section, which I feel was actually quite justified. I hope Prof Verma sees this and realizes that no learning happens if the correct answer is not given. Perhaps he believes in unsupervised learning, but the results of this can be unboundedly far from the global optimal. 

As an example of how ridiculous the technical expectations for this class is, during class Prof Verma regularly mentions Convex Optimization, some material from which is relevant in class. I looked up Convex Optimization and it is E6616 - a 6000-level course. If you're not prepared to deal with some 6000-course material that will not be explicitly taught to you, you may not want to take this Machine Learning course. I personally feel it is a shame because the material is super interesting and relevant, and could have been much better taught. A suggestion is a more depth, and less breadth, could improve the class significantly.

Overall, this class seems to reward prior knowledge, rather than diligence over the course, which is something I have an issue with.
reviews.workload: 4 problem sets, not too bad, just start on them early; and 2 exams. Forgot to mention that the last exam is before reading week which adds to the general sense that Verma doesn't really want people to be well-prepared for his exams at all.

reviews.content:
Professor Verma's ML section was definitely worthwhile. He's a clear lecturer and gave homework that really helped further develop the concepts we learn in class. But, be warned that the homework was difficult and time consuming, though this is somewhat mitigated by the fact that he allows students to form groups of 3 to work on homework together.

Tests were a mix of very easy questions and a couple rather hard questions. Some of the more in-depth math was fortunately not tested on exams, but there were some difficult theoretical problems. Overall, particularly with the curve, the tests were definitely manageable.

Personality wise, Prof. Verma is great. He cracks jokes during lecture and he really cares about his students. His OH often seemed to extend passed the slotted time so that he could continue to help students. His niceness was a bit of a drawback at times in that some students would occasionally eat up a lot of lecture asking basic or unnecessarily involved questions and he wouldn't cut them off, but he got better at handling this as the semester progressed.

Overall, this was a good course that'll teach you ML basics, but it will probably be one of the heavier workload courses you'll take in a semester.
reviews.workload:
Pretty heavy. 
4 problem sets with anywhere from 3-7 questions, many of them difficult but rewarding.
Midterm and final both not too hard, but not easy either.

reviews.content: The class is basically taught and graded entirely by the TAs who do not know how to grade. Grading was always late (2 of the 5 homework assignments were graded after the final exam) and feedback was terse. Omri doesn't seem to care about his students because he's too busy doing other things. Many times he wouldn't be in his office during his office hours. Take this class with other professors who will actually take their job seriously.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Easy homework, brutal exams (mind you, that's like 80% of your grade)

reviews.content:
The reviewer below clearly has not taken any advanced math class at Columbia. Omri's explanations of theoretical concepts is very good, and if you have any experience with proof based math courses, you will probably really enjoy his exposition. 

The reviewer is correct that lectures are the exact same as the textbook, but that doesnt mean that they are not worth going to; reading and understanding the textbook by yourself can take an extremely long time whereas Omri will streamline and highlight important parts of the proofs in class.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload:
Homeworks are straightforwards (can easily get 95+, but the averages were low)
Midterm was very easy 
Final was harder but pretty doable with a complete understanding of the material

reviews.content: Definitely not the best at explaining concepts, which is kind of critical considering that this course is very abstract and theoretical. It can also get very hard to take notes on his lecture because he often would not write down a complex idea he is talking about and/or scribble very few words about it. He does regurgitate the textbook almost verbatim, so you can totally get away with not attending class.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 1 problem set every roughly three weeks, which is reasonable. They can take a while to do, however, if you do not understand the material. Midterm was very straight forward and the class average was like 94%, but the final was atrocious. The average is not released at this time of writing but it is probably around 40%.

reviews.content:
So I took this course with Omri and he uses the textbook Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach. The course has its pros and cons. Look, Omri certainly knows the material but he is glued to the textbook. As I understand it he graduated from Princeton and thinks this book is the bees knees – the author is a professor there. The book is intense and I for one utilized other books and resources to build some bit of intuition for the material.

His lectures are interesting until you realize he is going straight from the book and fails to explain and expand on crucial concepts in different meaningful ways. He does not break down the proofs enough for the class to have any "ah-ha" moments. He assumes competency in the proofs and consistently says, "Come on guys, you should know this" as a constant response to any sort of confusion the class may have.

This is a graduate course and as such most students are Master/Phd students. If you are an undergraduate student, I would not take this course unless you are solid with rigorous proofs and have a solid mathematical intuition. Also, CS Theory is the pre-req course but it is a joke and very trivial compared to this course. There is a huge leap from messing around with Turing Machines in the first couple chapters of Sipser than jumping to Barak's material trying to fathom the complexity zoo.

The TAs were okay. Their grading was intense and they expected a lot from the students. Do not take this course if you think it will be an easy grade. I would take this course with Xi Chen or even Rocco who seem to dive deeper into the specific nuances of each proof. 

TLDR: Only take this course if you need it or are stellar in mathematical proofs, they will not hold your hand. Take with other professors for more in depth explanations of material.
reviews.workload:
10 Problem Sets
No Midterm
1 Final

reviews.content:
Though I have taken statistics and probability courses in the past, this course did a great job introducing me to new probability tools that are especially relevant to theoretical computer science. After defining basic information theory concepts, we applied them to the study of communication complexity, algorithm lower bounds, interactive compression, and data structures problems. The class convinced me that information theory is the "right" language to describe probability in computer science.

In terms of instruction, Omri did a pretty good job. He provided intuition for each definition and proof. However, I feel like he spent a little too long on introductory material; given this was a 6000-level class, I think most of the students would have been fine skipping a good chunk of introductory material, and we could have covered more.

course_header.course_name: Topics in Computer Science: Information Theory

reviews.workload:
4 homework assignments
1 lecture to scribe
1 final project based on reading and original research

reviews.content:
Lydia is a great professor. She is extremely energetic and her lectures are super engaging... which is shame because you really don't have to watch a single lecture (or even look at the slides) to do well in this class... The few times I did attend lectures, the examples of "good web design" were screenshots from the early 2010's (with website design typical of that time period) so I would say this class is a bit out dated. But nonetheless, this class is great at slowly developing your frontend skills from 0 to being able to build a fully functional website. The midterm and final projects are both fun to work on and the deadlines are super lenient. 
Easy A class, gives you great projects.
reviews.workload:
2 assignments per week (shouldn't take more than a couple hours)
1 midterm project
1 final project
(The projects take a decent amount of time and effort, but you get a lot of time)

reviews.content:
Professor Chilton's lectures are extremely engaging.
This class is easy (speaking from someone who doesn't have prior web dev experience). There are only assignments and projects, no exams. Assignments 1-6 helps you practice the web dev stuff you learn in class (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Bootstrap, JQuery, Flask). The Midterm project, which is an individual project, builds on to Assignment 6 (a database website with the topic of your choice) by adding more features and also focusing on graphic design. The Final project, which is encouraged to be done in groups (you choose your own groups as long as your group members are in your TA session, and you can make an exception with your TA to work on it individually), allows you to create a website teaching users a topic of your choice. 
Professor Chilton highly encourages students to use ChatGPT in their assignments and projects, which made this class easy. However, I would encourage you to still engage with the learning process to really benefit from this class. Even if ChatGPT doesn't help, there are 32 TAs holding OHs every week. Note that Professor Chilton does not give out any A+s.
Unlike HWs 1-6 and the projects, some parts in HWs 7-12, which were used to guide students in their final projects, felt like busy work, but I found many parts of them to be very helpful because you can create your prototype and your TA will give you feedback on it. Also, HW instructions often had typos, and I feel like sometimes in the lectures after Spring Break, Professor Chilton repeats the same topics.
Some HWs focused on website functionality, while others focused on both website functionality and graphic design. 
If you want to explore web dev (both the coding and graphic design aspects of it), check out this class!
reviews.workload:
12 (almost) weekly assignments (each counted for 5% of final grade), a Midterm project (10% of final grade), Final project (20% of final grade), participation and attendance in TA sessions after Spring Break (10% of final grade). Lecture attendance is not required, and Professor Chilton posts lecture recordings.
If you follow all the instructions in the HWs and projects and asked for feedback on your work, you will get a 100%. No A+ grades are given out.
BTW: TA sessions are basically these meetings you have with ~10 students and your TA (chosen by you if there's room in the session) each Wednesday after Spring break. Each group talks about their progress on their project/their work in HWs 7-12 and gets feedback from the TA. Before Spring break, lectures were on Mondays and Wednesdays. After Spring break, lectures were only on Mondays, with TA sessions (only 45 mins) being on Wednesdays.

reviews.content:
Expectations that this would be a fairly easy class. 
Overall, I think Lydia is an engaging instructor. Then again, I went to about two lectures total. 
The content of the class was fine, but pretty common sense. Classes would regularly end 30 minutes early and I stopped keeping up with lectures after the midterm.
reviews.workload:
There were 12 assignments total. The first 6 (before the midterm) were fully individual and exercises in recreating a UI or designing a mini-project. I thought these were super useful and were great practice. I really liked the midterm project, too.

But assignments 7-12 felt like 100% busywork. They were all geared toward completing the final project and guiding you along. As someone who doesn't deal well with microassignments that feel pointless, I waited until the last minute and did them all in one night. The final project itself was also pretty chill. I was able to finish half a semester's worth of work in one sitting, so do with that what you will.

reviews.content: I took UI with Lydia back during the Spring 2024 semester, and I would say it was a mostly solid experience! We had an opportunity to practice our HTML, CSS, and JavaScript skills and put together a project to showcase those skills. We also learned about design principles related to (as the course name suggests) user interface design – namely colors, negative space, gestalt principles, among other concepts. The class had very lenient grading, whereas once certain action items were completed for each of the assignments, full credit was given. I also found it really intriguing that Lydia encouraged the class to use ChatGPT to aid in the completion of the assignments. It created quite a contrast to other courses, where that would be heavily frowned upon. I would say that it’s allowed for by the structure of the class (project-based, and graded based on the nature of the product), compared to other classes, which would incorporate exams and be based on the content of the code used to create a product (and by extension, forbid ChatGPT). For Lydia herself, she was a fairly engaging lecturer and seemed relatively approachable for the most part – I can’t quite say since I’ve never attended office hours. I say “for the most part” for approachability because my group met with her for working on one of the final project phases and she didn’t like our idea and honestly ripped into it quite a bit. It felt frustrating and confusing for our group as a collective since some of her critiques went against what we were supposed to aim for for the project. Beyond that, it wasn’t that big of a deal since our TA graded the assignment.
reviews.workload: The class had “biweekly” homework assignments – 12 warm up assignments, then 12 main assignments total (60% of the grade). The last few assignments made up the final project (20%). After that, there was the midterm project (10%), then TA section participation when working on the final project (10%). The final project involved making a website to teach the user something they likely won’t already know in 10 minutes. It was split into multiple phases – coming up with ideas as individuals, narrowing down ideas as a group, selecting final ideas as a group, creating wireframes for the idea, coloring the wireframe, then lastly, coding up the website. The premise was to write it in HTML/CSS/JavaScript since that’s what we worked with throughout the semester, but we were also free to use libraries (Vue, React, Next, etc.). We personally used React with Tailwind and TypeScript. Grading is, again, fairly lenient, though the work itself can feel like a grind to work on, especially if you don’t start early and pace yourself accordingly. However, once you complete everything, you have a good shot of getting an A.

reviews.content:
I didn't go to lecture but I think it was very focused on design.
However assignments are very technical
Would recommend to CS majors looking to get projects on their resume because you make lots of websites for the class and learn web dev
reviews.workload:
Web dev assignments were a bit tedious
Easy A

reviews.content: Tony Dear is a very clear and detail-oriented lecturer. He's cares about helping his students succeed, whether that be making extra office hours or a generous curve. However there is a large gap between the examples walked through during class and the homework problems, and a similarly large gap between homework problems and exam problems. Class examples are the foundations but for homework problems you need to learn how to apply your base knowledge. Also reviewing for exams is less about how many problems you do and more about deeply understanding the concepts and solutions for the problems you do. Discrete problems require a level of creativity, so it's more important to just understand what's going on than to crank out extra practice. Problem sets were pretty time-consuming and for harder units like Mod I had to self-study external material to understand. Definitely utilize your resrouces: go to TA and professor office hours. He's hard but fair. I would say take him if you are generally curious, like a challenge, and don't mind putting in the time outside of class to deeply understand the content. If you want an easy A, take Discrete with Ansaf. Final exam was extremely hard, ~110/150 is a good score for an A typically.
reviews.workload: Problem sets took ~6 hours/week. Exams took ~8-10 hours of review.

reviews.content: Dear might possibly be the worst professor I've had at Columbia so far. He made easy concepts extremely difficult to understand and did not explain concepts well at all, would highly recommend people to not take this class with Dear. Exams were extremely difficult and expected students to be able to completely code out homework assignments without providing knowledge on how.
reviews.workload: 2 exams and homeworks every other week

reviews.content: I expected this class to be tough because of previous review, and it was, but it wasn't impossible. Really understanding the first few topics (especially everything to do with proofs) is super important because they reappear for almost the entire course. His teaching style is clear, he writes notes and works full examples for us, he answers as many questions as he can and overall seems direct and focused but friendly. The content was well organized, as was Ed, which he used to post lecture notes, practice midterms, etc. Attending recitations was a great place to understand how to attack harder problems like the ones on exams.
reviews.workload:
7 homework assignments, 2 midterms, and a final. 

The homework assignments are for the most part doable, a step above the notes with an occasional much more difficult problem. Maybe 4-6 hours a week for this.

The exams were much more difficult than the notes, and while recitations didn't match this thinking, they sometimes gave pointers on how to approach more difficult questions. Doing the practice exams and making sure you understand the solutions are crucial for the midterms, and for the final....just try to get as many points as you can.

reviews.content: I will admit, this class was tough. Prof Dear does a great job of explaining the course material, and always answers questions well. The subject, though, is proof-based, so you may understand all the concepts but might not know how to prove a certain problem. The exams in his class are also quite difficult, the final was the worst one. He posts practice exams that give you a decent idea of the topics included and the level of mastery you need, but using them as your only study material is not a good idea.
reviews.workload: 2 midterms, 15% each; 1 final, 35%; 7 homework assignments, 30%; participation quizzes, 5%. About 2 weeks to complete each homework assignment, each is around 6 questions with multiple parts per question. Participation quizzes are pop quizzes but they are completion grades: if you take all the quizzes, you have 100% for participation. You can make up a quiz by attending the recitation that week.

reviews.content: Prof. Dear is quite a good teacher overall, and lectures are very worth going to. The most common (and valid) complaint is that his exams are harder than his in-class examples. Since Discrete is proof-based, test difficulty often came from not being able to think of the correct route for a proof, which is hard to study for. I personally liked the class a lot, but experiences vary. If you have prior experience with competitive math/similar concepts, you should be fine.
reviews.workload: Biweekly homework (30%) + two midterms (30%) + final (35%) + participation (5%). Homework was decently heavy.

reviews.content: Everyone says that the class is really hard—and to be honest, it is quite a bit of work. However, I wouldn’t go as far as to say you should avoid Professor Dear at all costs. Discrete Math is an introduction to proof-based mathematics, so it's no surprise that it feels challenging at first. That said, Professor Dear's class is genuinely informative, which is especially valuable if you plan to do computer science in the future. The course follows a textbook, though a few chapters are skipped. In a nutshell, it was a tough but interesting class with a professor who is eager to explain topics you don’t understand
reviews.workload:
There were a total of seven problem sets, assigned roughly every two weeks. The exams were difficult and often went beyond the level of the homework and recitation questions, this gap became more noticeable as the semester progressed. The median score dropped significantly from the first midterm to the final. However, since the class is graded on a curve, it didn’t impact final grades as harshly as it might have otherwise. 

The main advice for anyone planning to take this class with Professor Tony Dear is simple: show up. Attend every lecture and recitation, start working on the homework early, and make use of office hours. It’s extremely difficult to succeed in this class without putting in the work—unless you already have a strong background in proof-based mathematics. On average, I spent about 12 hours per week on this class. Sometimes it was less, but during exam weeks, it could be as much as 20 hours.

reviews.content: Tony Dear is a great lecturer - when it comes to delivering the material in the classroom. His exams are crazy, with questions that never even resembled the level of the HW (which were not easy but manageable). All in all -  a very tricky course. I would recommend taking with Ansaf. Avoid Tony at all costs.
reviews.workload: Super busy schedule. Teaching new material for HW that's due in 2 days from now. 2 midterms, 1 final. Final was the most tough exam I took at Columbia.

reviews.content: I actually don't mind Tony's teaching style unlike many of my peers as I do believe walking through the notes is helpful and he does appear to be a nice professor but the difficulty of his class is just unwarranted and absurd.
reviews.workload: We had bi weekly Psets that were pretty difficult but manageable which would take around 6-8 hours to do but it's the examinations, especially the final, that makes this class stupid. For some odd reason, he decided that it would be a good idea to not only make the final significantly harder than the two mid terms, but even than the Psets, which we had days to do. He also incorporates a lot of CS theory on these problems so that a simple combinatorics problem isn't your usual counting cards or numbers but of neural networks and nodes.

reviews.content: Honestly, taking this class was easily one of my worst experiences at Columbia even compared to other more difficult CS classes. If you have a limited math background I would 100% avoid taking this class with him, as he really expects you to have higher level math knowledge even though calc I is the only stated prerequisite. I found him to be very nice but not a very good lecturer or teacher, I had to go to office hours or spend time teaching myself everything in this class from online resources because he taught with very vague examples or just didn't teach things needed for the homework. Along with that he would always say to start the homework early and would give assignments 2 weeks beforehand, but wouldn't teach concepts needed to do a lot of those problems until sometimes the class before it was due. Overall, I just felt like this class was made intentionally difficult when it didn't need to be, and he should have spent more time teaching basic concepts thoroughly as well as actually teaching what we needed for the homework. This class to me exemplifies everything wrong with classes at Columbia. Especially given that this is a 4 credit class, I expected a lot more and definitely better organization. Also, just be warned that his tests are very difficult and will test you on things outside of the content you learn in class.
reviews.workload: Grading was very harsh at times, but fair for other assignments. There were 2 midterms, 1 final, and homework that was due about once every 2 weeks.

reviews.content: To be frank, the exams in this class were some of the hardest I've ever taken (And I'm a CS SEAS major) and a step above the given homework problems (not great). Would put this class at the same level of difficulty as Advanced Programming, Discrete Math, and Mutlivariable Calculus. No qualms with the Professor, though - nice, approachable, willing to help as much as possible.
reviews.workload: Honestly, I wouldn't take this class unless you absolutely have to. It's just another tough thing to deal with.

reviews.content: Take a class with Christos!! He cares a lot about his students and is a fascinating and wonderful person to know. His office hours have been one of the best parts of my college experience. His psets are difficult, but he is flexible, helpful, and brilliant. Also, he is the author of multiple novels and a wonderful comic book series called logicomix. Ask him about it in his office hour sometime.
reviews.workload: One difficult pset a week. They took me about 5-10 hours depending on the pset, and they had to be typed.

reviews.content:
Christos Papadimitriou is easily one of the best teachers, not just in the CS department, but at the whole university. Rather then just writing summaries of the text book on the board for students to copy, he actually engages the students and instills the core principles of concepts in each lecture. He also adds fun historical facts and jokes throughout his lectures. His weekly psets were quite challenging, but that’s by nature of the subject. Christos doesn’t hide the fact that his psets are challenging, and consistently encourages students. He even throws “homework parties” during the semester, where he books a conference room and orders food, and lets students collaborate on the give. Pset together. I’ve never had a teacher more invested in their students success. 

As an added bonus, Christos isn’t just some random lecturer. He’s one of the most famous and accomplished  theoretical computer scientists in the world. Having access to such a legend is truly astonishing. In his office hours, he’s willing to discuss anything research related. He’s also one of the most charismatic people I’ve ever met. If you’re lucky enough to be able to take a class with Christos, take it!
reviews.workload: Weekly psets (difficult), midterm, final, weekly (optional) quizzes for bonus points

reviews.content: This class had the coolest content I have ever learned at Columbia. Even if you don't know if you're interested in programming languages and compilers, I would still recommend this class. By the end of the class, you will have an entirely original compiler that you and your group built yourself. It's still kind of insane to me that a topic as complicated as compilers can be conveyed in such a modular and actually understandable way. Professor Gu is super approachable and knowledgable. You also learn OCaml, which is a super weird and fun language.
reviews.workload: Not a light workload but absolutely manageable. 4ish problem sets, which are a combination of OCaml programming and theoretical questions about the algorithms/tools learned in class. The problem sets aren't particularly difficult once you get a hang of OCaml. The midterm and final were also both super manageable, the professor and TAs pretty clearly lay out what is going to be on the test, most questions are different versions of problems done in class. The bulk of the work comes in a semester long project where you implement a compiler from the ground up. This is a pretty big undertaking, but if you do it incrementally and work on the parts of the compiler as they are taught in class, it will be very doable. The project is done in a group of 6, so it's pretty important that you have a good group to make this project much more manageable since it is a considerable amount of work.

reviews.content:
Avoid this professor at all costs, take with another professor if possible. 
Very unprepared professor, constantly had mistakes when teaching the class. The content was interesting, however it was just not taught very well. 
Very poorly written exams, with very poorly written rubrics. Sometimes there was no space given to write your solutions to the questions.
No midterm/final practice exams. There was a midterm/final review but they were nothing like what was on the exam.

We didn't recieve homework solutions (main homework) before the midterm, so it was really hard to study for. 

There's extra credit, but it doesn't make up for the curving of the grades down. The extra credit wasn't graded for the pop quizzes/ assignment until several weeks after the final exam.
reviews.workload:
~6 hrs a week on average.
Terrible grading style, only about 3 things were graded before the final exam so you had no idea how you were doing.
Not even sure how they graded the projects, because it seemed like everyone got 100% even though that shouldn't have happened,
so that resulted in her curving the grades down:

A  = 97+ (~93rd percentile)
A- = 93+ (~78 percentile)
B+ =90+ (~70th percentile)
B = 86+ (~40 percentile)
B- = 80+ (~14 percentile)
C+ = 72+ (~3.6 percentile)
C = rest

So basically, if you did average on the exams, you got between B- and B.

reviews.content: I liked the content of this class, and Professor Baishakhi is nice and approachable and her lectures are somewhat entertaining. However, she does not care about her students and does not know the content well at all. She made countless mistakes throughout the lectures that students would correct. She would take an agonizing amount of time going through content that was covered in required prerequisites. Her homework was fun and challenging but graded without feedback. And the final grade was curved down. She is a nice person but not a good professor. If you can, take this class with a different professor.
reviews.workload: 3 assignments which felt like too little. Very little prep is given for exams. On average I spent about 5 hours a week on this class (outside of class)

reviews.content: One of the worst professors I’ve ever had at Columbia. She is highly disorganized, with slides often not being uploaded, even as late as the week leading up to finals. The teaching team is extremely unresponsive to emails and ed posts. Exam, homework, and project instructions/questions are often not worded properly, and requests for clarification often go unanswered. Grading deadlines are rarely met - by the time finals approached, only HW1 and Programming Assignment 1 had been graded. While the course content is interesting, the professor’s poor management makes this class one of the worst at Columbia.
reviews.workload: 3 written hw, 3 programming assignments (4 but the last one is optional), 1 midterm, 1 final

reviews.content: The professor is very disorganized.
reviews.workload: There are 4 written assignments, each is at least 4 pages long, and each assignment is only worth 2.5% of overall grade...

reviews.content:
Very disorganized professor - every homework/programming assignment needed last minute clarifications. 

Teaching was disorganized (didn't learn a single thing from lecture), and what was discussed in lecture was completely different from the homeworks. Doing the homework assignments depended on going through the source code of LLVM, navigating around documentation on your own, and trying to figure out what was going on. This was justified by the professor because she said that obviously theory taught in class will be different from applications on homeworks. But had a student not posted a Google Doc on Piazza of research that she had compiled and shared with the class, honestly I wouldn't even know what LLVM is. Grading was very arbitrary.

Overall, I think the professor cares very much about teaching her students and making sure that we understand. This is apparent because she took time in class to ask for and answer questions. However, I had no questions because I didn't even know what to ask. All her slides are also adopted from other professors and better versions can be found online.

I would recommend taking PLT with any other professor if possible.
reviews.workload:
3 written homework assignments; 5 programming assignments
1 midterm, 1 final on the last day of classes

reviews.content: Incredibly poorly run class. Homework grades released months after assignments were submitted, rarely in time for exams. Only 1 homework covered material on the final exam, incomplete answers were released 5 hours before the final. Programming based assignments barely reflected theory learned in class, most of the work was done in reading documentation of the framework we were working in. Professor refused to release answers to last programming assignment publicly (answers required for extra credit assignment due during finals period), and students had to chase after TAs to get the solutions mailed individually.
reviews.workload: 5-8 hrs a week

reviews.content:
I took this class in Spring 2022, so some of these details might be outdated for the current version of the course. Nevertheless, Prof. Vondrick is an excellent lecturer who deserves more reviews here.

The class was very straightforward and assumed no prior knowledge of composer vision. Prof. Vondrick went over every topic carefully, and the his lecture slides were crystal clear. The coding homework assignments with Python and PyTorch were also easy, but HW2 might take longer since you have to build a neural network from scratch. The rest can be knocked out in an hour or two though.

The final quiz was also a breeze if you paid attention in class. In fact, Prof. Vondrick dropped hints for most of the final's questions and their answers throughout the semester, so it's in your best interest to go to class or watch the Zoom recordings.

Grading was more than fair. There were two strategies to assign letter grades and Prof. Vondrick automatically picked the strategy that gave you the best grade. The first strategy was a curve. The second strategy was the standard grading scale:
90% overall guarantees at least A-
80% overall guarantees at least B-
70% overall guarantees at least C-

Most people finished with an A. The few who didn't got an A- instead.
reviews.workload:
HW0 - 5%
HW1-5 - 10% each
Final Quiz - 45%

reviews.content:
Somehow there's no review on Prof Vondrick yet despite him teaching here for two? three? years now, so I thought I'd get it started.

Overall, I really enjoyed his lectures. The earlier lectures on image processing were simply mind-blowing to me and a good foundation on accessing the field of computer vision. Past neural networks, it gets a little hand-wavey (as classes tend to, as I've learnt, after deep learning comes in and dominates the field) because Prof. Vondrick doesn't really get into the details of constructing a neural network tailored to CV, and talking about theory on a powerpoint only gets you so far. However, he continues to give great theoretical intuition on how the math/techniques work. You can tell he is a brilliant man.

Pretty good class and I learnt a good deal. Helps to have linear algebra and some algorithms prerequisites (even more helpful to have taken a class on deep learning) as he goes through some concepts assuming the class already knows them.
reviews.workload:
7 assignments, difficulty varies. The easiest took less than an hour and the hardest ~10 hours. Implementation of algorithms in python.
Final quiz covering lecture materials.

reviews.content:
Bland professor, with unengaging presentation and informative slides that capture a handful of core NLP algorithms and concepts. You are better off not attending the meaningless lectures that include little elaboration of slides, mundane anecdotes/tangents, and students trying to show off through their questions.
A standard course that requires medium to little effort and teaches useful information, however the course is incredibly boring to attend - despite how interesting the subject is and its applications can be.

Benajiba is obsessed with the fact that he works in the industry. That usually translates well to teaching, but he just reads off of slides and doesn't end up teaching much. I would pick one of the other professors simply by virtue of being able to actually learn stuff. He goes over neural network architectures but doesn't actually explain how they work. He more just says "here! this is an architecture! here's a diagram!" 
But wait! There's worse! He curves down! How much, you ask? Right after giving the final lecture about the curses of overfitting, he releases final exam grades and says that a 94 equates to an A-. That's right, a 93.9 is a B+, when the average on the final exam was in the 80s. 
I would avoid him at all costs. If you want to learn NLP, go to another professor. If you want a good grade, go to another professor. The only reason you should want to take a class with him is if you need the credits and are Pass/Failing his class since his threshold for a pass is 49%.

Yassine is not a great instructor and he mostly just reads off of Prof. Bauer's slides. The curriculum itself is pretty dry and is mostly focused on semantic and dependency parsing, with a little bit of neural models thrown in at the end. I don't think I can actually do anything useful with what I learned in this class. Given that its a COMS 4xxx class, there are lots of MS students in the class who want to impress him, and mostly end up talking to him about GPT-3 or some other research paper the entire time; he gets off topic very easily. His homeworks are incredibly easy and also taken from Prof. Bauer, and exams are very easy as well. However, this is a big problem, since most of the class will end up with 90+ on everything, so he curves down. He required a 94 for an A-; that's right, folks, your 93.9 is a B+. This is absolutely ridiculous in my opinion and he needs to reassess how he evaluates us since one small mistake will be the difference between an A and a B+. I do not recommend this class at all; if you must take NLP, at least take it with someone else.

The homeworks are all graded leniently and the exams are very straightforward. Similar sentiments with the other reviews. However, beware that while you might get decent scores on the homework and exams, the final grades are based on a curve. This includes curving downward. Apparently averages were higher this semester, and an A was a 96% or higher, an A- was a 94-96%, and a B+ was a 89-94%.

His in-person 3-hour lectures were sometimes dry, but I think that had more to do with the fact it was on Friday and back to back then him as a lecturer. I thoroughly enjoyed watching his lectures at my own pace on video and I really appreciate all the extra tidbits he brought to class- book recommendations, funny videos showing a concept, research papers, interview advice. He clearly cares about his students and does a good job sharing his passion for NLP with interested students. 

This was my favorite CS class by far. The programming projects are fun and challenging and give you the tools to start your own NLP projects.

If you pay attention and class and go to recitation, the exams are not too difficult.
reviews.workload:
bi-weekly homework (leniently graded) 50%
midterm 20%
final 30%

reviews.content:
Some of the best professors I've had at Columbia and I've taken many classes with some of the most popular profs in different departments. I understand why a few people might find the class dry but I think the bitterness is mostly due to the workload and the rigor of the course. While the material is not rocket science, it takes a certain focus and imagination to see the bigger picture in the field of NLP. Yassine clearly knows a lot and is always excited about bringing to class some of the latest developments in NLP. I personally love the intuitive way in which he explains things and never feel the need to read much beyond attending the lectures. And that's how it should be.

The homework problems can be a bit annoying especially the do-the-algorithm by hand part but it also definitely helps with understanding how things work. The programming assignments are super fun and some of the best I've had in the department. We're provided with a  clean scaffolding of the code which is unseen in any of the Intelligent Systems track classes. Because of that I feel like we don't get dragged into writing stupid and time-consuming systems around the crux of whatever we're learning. You just get into writing the NLP model/algorithm.
reviews.workload:
bi-weekly assignments
midterm - final
should be an easy A if you pay attention in class

reviews.content: absolutely useless, learnt nothing.
reviews.workload: heavy

reviews.content: Don't listen to the haters. This class was fantastic. It was a bit disorganized sometimes, to be fair, but that ended up affecting my experience barely marginally.  If you're paying attention in class, you will learn so much.  Papa goes through a ton of material, but it's all very meaningful; we covered some really cool topics like game theory and quantum computing.  Papa is a living legend and you can tell.  He's an expert on these areas to the nth degree and knows how to teach it effectively and kindly.  Definitely an amazing teacher.  The TAs were honestly very good.  Prompt with Piazza questions, and as accommodating as possible.  Take this class if you want to put in a bit of work, but want to get a lot out of it as well.

Just want to mention, with overwhelming bad reviews, the first two reviews (which happen when everything is in person) are overwhelmingly good. I actually take this course due to those reviews.
I do think Professor Papadimitriou is nice and knowledgable, and I don't know what happen to the course for this online version. 
Just want to point to the reviews for in-person course so that people can have their own judgement.

I really do not know how people got through his lectures in person. His zoom class was a disaster, from the TAs to the exams to homework assignments. Awful and painful class. It's funny that he confuses himself a lot of times, and then ask "IS IT CLEAR?" How the hell it is clear when you don't even know what you are talking about!!! He really is a super nice and approachable professor. He smiles all the time and answers your questions and replies to your email, but that really doesn't change how bad this class is.

This was a truly horrible class. Do not take this with Papa, whatever you do. Just because he's famous doesn't mean he can teach or explain. Insane workload, lots of it not on important/relevant topics to what most people actually care about algorithms for - interviews.
Do yourself a favor, take this with literally anyone else. Better yet, pray that you have TAs that care enough about students to change the direction of a terribly run course.

LMAO how much are we willing to bet that one of the butthurt TAs wrote the review from April 6? It’s obviously a bullshit review made to save face.
Anyways, all the other reviews from 2021 are completely accurate. I agree that Christos is probably a nice person, it’s just his lack of organization and terrible TAs that make this class trash. The format of a Zoom semester plays a hand in it too, but I honestly don’t think things would be that much different if we were in-person with the same TAs.

I have a lot to say about this class, some of which is in response to what has already been said. I'll try to keep my argument structured and evidenced and give my final review at the end. For context, I'm an undergraduate junior who's already taken enough 4000 level classes in the department to feel confident vouching for these opinions. 
1. First things first, I agree with the other posts on the disorganization and intense workload of the class. Analysis of Algos is one of the most intense workload classes I've taken at Columbia (not the hardest, but a lot of work). It would've helped to have a reasonable routine for problem sets and for quizzes/readings, and it is really troubling that this was not followed. I agree that as a class, it's insane that we have to deal with this in the middle of an online sem. It's also crazy how a little bit of everything counts, so you cannot really slack off on any parts. The lectures are very fast, and it's not possible to keep up with the class at all points of time, with the readings the core resource in helping to follow. 
2. I do not agree with the assessment of the TAs, and especially name-dropping of the TAs in the post -- it's unfair and gives a very biased view of what happens in class. In my opinion, Max Helman and the team (despite their quirks) have done their best to be helpful. I think the grading is a bit too harsh with too many requirements, and rubrics need to be more precise, but this is common to most Algos sections. Previous posts mention that its ridiculous to have 3 hws, a project and a final in the final weeks of the class and I fully agree, but it's worth noting that the students voted to have a project to take the weight off of the final, and that the TA team orchestrated that the request was heard. I too voted for the project and it was a bad decision in hindsight, but this was not a TA decision to add more work. In my opinion, the TA team has been resourceful and responsive on Piazza despite being uncertain from time to time about logistics which I doubt were in their control. I had many instances asking for readings + homework, and was told that this decision had not been taken on a professor level despite them following up. This brings me to my final point:
3. Christos Papidimitriou is a legend of the CS world. He teaches this class once in a while because he feels like it, and out of a pure passion for algorithms. The passion is apparent in his fast-paced lecturing style and the breadth of his syllabus. It's very rare to have a professor who's written the textbook of the class, and even rarer to have one of the smartest people in the world as your Prof with the crazy CS network Prof. Christos has: including the likes of the founding members of Google and Microsoft and several dozen Turing Award winners and award-winning textbook authors that are his friends. He has contributed to evolutionary biology as he has to game theory, to complexity theory as he to database theory. I think when people sign up for his class, people are looking for the experience of learning from a 'famous' professor. And I think the disorganization in the class is purely a consequence of the same: he's a very busy person who wants to say a lot about a lot of things. This by no means is trying to say it's ok to not pay attention to the requirements of the students. As I've said before, I disagree with how lectures and organization for the class went. I just think that the status of Prof. Christos's achievements along with the fact that he infrequently teaches the course means that the structure can get a bit haywire, not as a consequence of TA involvement but rather purely as an artifact of everything he wants to cover and how he relays this.
Finally, I want to note all this is true of a zoom semester. There's close to no interaction in the lectures or breakout rooms and it's so easy to fall behind in class, after which the mandatory attendance requirement means that loads of people attend for the sake of it. naturally, the online learning environment does not lend itself to question answering beyond those that are already confident of the material and this contributes to the issue. I would not generalize from what I've written above or what others have written of the Spring 2021 iteration to beyond the online medium. 
Final outcome: 

Agree with: heavy workload, fast lectures, disorganized content

Disagree with: evaluation of the intentions and commitments of teaching staff. I think they've tried their best to help through the semester and the haywire experience is more a consequence of the general direction of the syllabus + online medium.

Summary: take this class if you want the experience of having prof. Papadimitriou as your professor and want to flex about it for the rest of your Columbia journey and CS education career for when he wins his next big award. Don't take it if you expect light workload + easy psets related to the core algorithms taught in a more traditional algorithms sequence. Don't make a decision on whether to take it from looking at the TAs, but instead do so based on your expectations for the class. I doubt a change of staff will do one bit to alter the direction Prof. Christos takes his syllabus and expectations.
Painful, painful class. Do not take it if Max Helman is the head TA.

Agree with the top review. I really want to like him but this class has been the most awful experience I've had at Columbia. Only take this class if you are extremely self-disciplined and a genius in CS. A lot of people in this class are graduate school students, so if you are an undergraduate, be prepared to get lost at the beginning of the class. There are almost 100 people in this class, but there really aren't too many people participating due to the poor lecture structure and his teaching. I don't understand the majority of the things he teaches and have to rely on the textbook and self-learning 99% of the time. As an undergrad, I think this probably doesn't apply to a lot of the classmates coz there are a lot of graduate students, who probably have already seen most of the things taught in this class. Even though it's on zoom, he requires attendance, but I can't follow at all. There are always geniuses in this class who understand everything and make the professor think that everyone in the class understands what he's talking about. He enjoys putting us into breakout rooms, but NO ONE, literally NO ONE, talks in the breakout room (I'm not even sure whether people are actually listening to the course). He goes through everything pretty fast because you are supposed to understand everything deeply in the textbook before coming to the class, so you are basically fu.ked up if you don't do the readings. The content of this course is super important, but I really don't recommend Christos at all unless you learn everything on your own.

He seems like a nice guy and I really want to like him, but he has been a terrible professor this semester. I want to preface this with the fact that I am taking his algos class during a Zoom semester, so I'm sure it's hard for everyone, including the TAs and the professor, but the class is incredibly disorganized. We have mandatory quizzes before every lecture on the lecture material (which, although aren't worth a lot of our grades, are still stressful to have to worry about). The readings that these quizzes will be on and the quiz itself are often not posted until 10 PM or later the day before our 10:10 AM class, and we are supposed to take the quizzes before the lecture starts. Weekly psets are also sometimes posted late (posted Friday and due before Wednesday morning). Piazza is the main medium of communication, which is messy and it's difficult to find important messages.

All in all, I would not recommend this class at all.

Took in Spring 2024. A very chill upper level course, all things considered. Topics include special graphs (trees, bipartite, etc), planar graphs, graph coloring, matching, random graphs. Mostly follows Robin Wilson’s textbook on Graph Theory. 

Pros: 
* Yihao is super kind. She’s also quite response on EdStem / will give clear answers to any questions you have on lecture material / homework questions. 
* She’s the type to be quite clear on what to expect out of exams, and exam materials / homework questions are never things out of the blue. She also usually spares the class by not putting any exam questions that pertain to the most difficult topics in the course. 

Cons:
* Her lectures are a bit boring? She moves pretty slow through the slides, but that is arguably a good thing if you are just trying to breeze through a class 
* Lecture slides are sometimes a bit too succinct to be clear what’s actually going on, but also the textbook is readily available online and it can help patch up any holes you may have. 
* Because the class size is so small, it may be a little difficult to get a “good” Grade, since she curves the median to a 90. 

Ultimately, I’d say take the course if you a) want an easy, straightforward CS course to take and/or b) you are actually interested in graph theory. If not, it’s probably not worth your time.
reviews.workload:
Just note that Yihao literally considers her class to be a PRECURSOR to Algos 4231. So her expectations are not high. 

5 homeworks, 1 is dropped (30%). They are usually 4-5 questions (multiple parts), and quite related to lecture material. I didn’t find them too difficult. I could probably finish them in 2-8 hours, including typing out my answers. 
* Also, she usually gives hints for the most difficult questions, or will point you to a corresponding proof / theorem in the lectures to help guide you. 

1 midterm (35%), and 1 final (35%) Both are very similar styles: 1.5-2 hours, and just  a handful of Free response / proof type questions. You get a cheat sheet.

reviews.content: I strongly enjoyed this class. I think I have more experience with proofs/upper level math classes than most CS undergrads, which likely contributed to my enjoyment, but nonetheless Josh is a wonderful and caring guy. I sat in the front and raised my hand frequently, which is so uncommon for me but something about him just brought that out. Would recommend.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 6 homeworks, lowest was dropped, bonus problems on all of them worth up to an extra 15%, 1 midterm and final. Spent 5-10hrs a week on this class

reviews.content:
Josh is a very active and engaging lecturer. He always works through problems on the chalk board and never uses pre-written slides (which is great for a class like cs theory). His weekly office hours are accessible and he is very easily approachable. He is willing to work through even the simplest problems, and answers all questions in great depth, even if they are trivial. His grading is incredibly quick; the turnaround for homework and exams is no longer than a day. If grading mistakes are made, there is a fair and efficient appeals process. 

I personally found the material to be very interesting, especially from a Mathematical perspective; for an "intro" theory class quite a few topics were covered. However, I wish that we spent more time on the topics surrounding Complexity.

Overall, I am very pleased with this course.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: 1 Homework assignment every two weeks. 5 problems per homework. The questions are challenging and often require much consideration, but they are far from impossible. 1 midterm and 1 exam; lots of preparation materials are provided. The midterm and exams were not punitive and fairly assessed our knowledge of the subject. In general, all was very well balanced.

reviews.content: Such a smart and caring professor. Definitely take CS Theory with Josh if you can. His classes are interactive if you go in person and he always encourages participation. I felt extremely comfortable raising my hand for questions and guesses.

course_header.course_name: Computer Science Theory: Computability - Models - Computation

reviews.workload: Grading was fair. I took this class after taking most of my CS electives (4000 level) so it wasn't bad. 1 midterm, final, and 6 homework assignments with the lowest grade being dropped.

reviews.content: Incredibly applicable, and I've had 10+ years of professional experience working with ML engineers + data scientists. If you want to do DS / ML, take this! Also, very reasonable workload.
reviews.workload: Reasonable workload. Assignments were fairly easy.

reviews.content: Very easy A and very useful for ML interviews! Cool final project for your resume! Professor Pappu is very approachable and told students all the time to come to him if they want any career advice because he works in industry.
reviews.workload: Very easy A

reviews.content:
The CS department needs more of these hands-on classes in its catalogue. Compared to how theory-heavy classes like ML with Verma and Algos can get, AML with Prof. Pappu felt like a welcome breath of fresh air.

Prof. Pappu is a strong lecturer. This course covers everything you need to know for introductory MLE interviews, spanning from the foundations of classical ML techniques all the way to modern practices like recommender systems. Although that seems like a lot of content to cover in a single semester, Prof. Pappu's slides are organized and intuitive enough for even a beginner to follow along.

Grading is quite lenient, and even Prof. Pappu doesn't sugarcoat it on the first day of class—he admits that the rumors are true and that even a 5th grader could ace his course. So if you're looking for an easy elective, I'd highly recommend AML.
reviews.workload:
Homework (50%)
Midterm (20%)
Final Project (30%)

The homework assignments are like worksheets that are done in Jupyter notebooks. Most of them involve using Pandas, scikit-learn, and Tensorflow to replicate what was shown in class.

The midterm is roughly 26-28 short answer questions. There might be a few curveballs, but the majority of the questions are taken directly from the lecture slides. The mean was 84.5, and the median was 88.

The final project is very flexible with little to no hard requirements. However, teams are randomly assigned, so you may have to put in more effort if your team ends up being useless (like mine).

There's no curve because most people get full scores on everything. An A+ is easily doable if you can ace the midterm since that's the only differentiator.

reviews.content: Applied course, lot of value addition. Will help during interviews
reviews.workload: Not that much, grading is nice. Can get a A easily.

reviews.content: This prof isn't great. He's formal, uses lots of slides, but doesn't teach much. Most students don't pay attention. You won't learn as much as other classes or doing competitive programming on your own. Many drop out early. Think before deciding.
reviews.workload: You will end up spending way more time that you thought you would

reviews.content:
TLDR: An above-average professor with an above-average workload, but (imo) incredibly interesting course material. The foundation you learn in this class will certainly help you apply causal inference to other applicable fields, like ML or data science (but don't expect to LEARN how to apply causal inference to other fields in this class). 

Took Causal Inference I fall 2023. One thing to note is that Bareinboim definitely knows his stuff, and is definitely one of the top causal profs in the field - he did his PhD under Judea Pearl, one of the most significant contributors to the causal field in contemporary times. 

The class is solely focused on the probability and models that drive our theories and frameworks of causality. You will not code at all, and the most he goes into applying the ideas to other hot fields, like ML or data science, is in the very last lecture, which you aren't tested on anyways. This is not a diss to the class - I personally loved learning about the math and theoretical backing.

Bareinboim lectures primarily using his slides - the slides are honestly quite decent, though sometimes certain slides can be difficult to parse without hearing him go over them in lecture, which he unfortunately doesn't record. He will occasionally scribble diagrams and math on the whiteboard, but they are usually incredibly messy and tangents anyways. Ultimately, he's a solid lecturer, but definitely not that entertaining / engaging, but imo that's few and far between in the CS dept in general. 

Oh, he also provides free access to this online software he, or his lab, created (I believe), which basically allows you to build causal graphs and automatically calculate important causal relationships from them. This is honestly so amazing, as it can basically calculate a third of the problems (the easiest ones) on the homeworks for you, and more importantly really helps when you are trying to digest some of the concepts and just want to tinker see how some of the messy theoretical concepts he describes in class actually applies to sample causal graphs. 

Probably my biggest irk for the class was how difficult it was to get help from OH. There was only one TA and Bareinboim himself that offered OHs each week, and so usually there would be swaths of students scrambling to ask them questions about the HW during the OHs. Oh well. Just try to take the course with a friend, and you can avoid the OH mess by just working together on homeworks.
reviews.workload:
4 homeworks (30%) 
Midterm (35%) 
Final (35%)

Homeworks are problems straight out of his own (unpublished, WIP) textbook. They range from superbly easy questions, to ones that definitely extend beyond the lectures and test how well you really know the material. Overall, I likely spent 10-15 hours on each homework, excluding writing them up in latex. 

Midterm and final are both 2-hour onslaughts. They are long. The questions are fair, and not out of this world difficult. The hardest will usually just be applying what you learned in lectures to a novel situation. I think the average for both was in the 50-60%, which actually isn't horrible compared to some other Columbia CS courses, but the std dev was tight - the max for both fell around 75%. I really don't think Bareinboim expects you to finish these exams, unless you are literally cracked. 

Silver lining is that for both homeworks and exams, they are generally lenient on partial credit.

reviews.content: Henry seems like a very nice guy, easily approachable and friendly. Unfortunately, he doesn't lecture or explain well at all, and has a tendency to push back deadlines and homeworks with no warnings or compensation. The exams and psets are insanely difficult and don't cover any of the class material. He will choose the topics that were barely explained in class and decide to focus a big portion of the exam on those topics. Does not reward hard work at all - the class is aimed at people who are specializing in CS theory. This is not an intro class.
reviews.workload: 15+ hours per week on HW and office hours

reviews.content:
Would highly recommend taking a class with Henry if you have the chance. I took computational complexity with him, not quantum computing, which his research focuses on, and he was amazing. The class is very difficult in terms of content but it is also incredibly rewarding and interesting. If you are tired of 300 person lectures this class is perfect. 

 Henry and the TAs were very approachable and helpful in office hours. If you attend lecture and office hours I think the PSETS are doable if you don't start them last minute. They are also spread out so that you have sufficient time to complete.
reviews.workload:
4 PSETs that are each 15% of the grade
Midterm and Final are each 20% and they are take-home.
The PSETs were incredibly time consuming, taking upwards of 20 hours each. You have to start them in advance

reviews.content:
I personally like it a lot and will highly recommend it, but I will provide some context.
Context: I take some courses in physics (quantum mechanics), math (abstract algebra), TCS (complexity theory, algorithms etc.), so I'm quite conformable with proofs, abstract concepts, and quantum weirdness.  Also due to these experiences, I get pretty accustomed to learning by myself via notes from class (or textbooks). So given these, I still feel the class is a relatively hard one.
Professor Henry: Absolute nice and approachable. I believe he is the only professor currently specializing in quantum computing (a lot of big names probably also research on these, but I guess it's not a thing in their times and they don't do courses on his.) He is knowledgeable about the field, but perhaps due to his age and also the online format, I guess the lectures can be somewhat unstructured. Also, I believe he has never taught the topic to an undergraduate class, so he might have a slight over-expectation for this class.
Lectures: Amazing and exciting! Quantum computing is so different from classical computing that you will feel like you are studying the frontier of science, and indeed we learn about all basic quantum computing stuff you probably heard from pop-science articles (Shor's prime factoring, Grover search, quantum teleportation...), rigorously. The downside is the materials are quite dense and I can imagine many students will feel a but overwhelmed (plus a bit unstructured mentioned above). I believe the class will get even better when you guys take it given Henry will get more experienced
Psets: there are only six psets (a pset0 for entry test and 5 normal psets) with no exams (originally the final exam is an additional pset but canceled). They are on average quite long, and one or two of them are quite hard (need to think hard). Many questions correspond to derivations that we don't have time to go over in class, which I like. Many other questions map to research papers in the field (I guess important/foundational ones) as an extension to the class material. Professor tries to guide us through the process in the psets, but they can be still quite hard (even when I find the corresponding papers) and take some time. But overall, I like them and I think they are very informative, useful, and fun. Like the lectures, I believe the psets will get updated and become much more manageable and even more fun.
Overall: hard class(for CS students who haven't done a lot of theoretical classes), but very fun. Plus, I believe it will get even better in the future.

I enrolled in this class based on the positive reviews I saw, but it turned out to be one of the worst decisions I've made. While the overall workload isn't significantly heavier than other CS classes, the disorganization and the behavior of the TAs stripped away my sanity. 
To be fair, the professor’s passion for the subject is undeniable, but the class itself feels like a chaotic experiment.
