It often seems like we’re being used as part of an iterative trial-and-error process. Unfortunately, the TAs only make things worse. They are unhelpful, disrespectful to students, and difficult to work with(at least for the ones I had contact with). Scheduling mandatory group meetings is a challenge, questions on Ed rarely get answered, and the grading process—despite having a rubric—feels subjective and unclear.
The TA assigned to my group, in particular, made the experience far worse(one is the head TA). They seemed entitled, focused more on their own preferences than on supporting students. For instance, we were required to submit video explanations for coding assignments (because grading code directly was "too much trouble"), and the TAs insisted the video links be included in multiple places—like the README file, Gradescope, and sometimes even an answer PDF. If there were mistakes in the homework instructions, they wouldn’t clarify or answer questions, which only added to the confusion.
I’ve also heard there are some good TAs in the course, but unfortunately, my experience was very different. Unless you absolutely need to take this class now, I would recommend waiting for updated reviews from future semesters to see if the issues improve.
reviews.workload: 5 long-winded individual HW; 5 group project checkpoints; 4 mandatory TA meetings for the project; A bunch of pre-class quizzes, which showed up at random times, so you had to constantly check to avoid missing them. I’ve never had a class where a quiz was posted after midnight, asking for slides for a same-day debate.

reviews.content:
I had a conversation with a TA who had assisted for several years, and they mentioned that Prof. Smith changed the syllabus and assignments significantly this year. Unlike previous years, each of the five homework assignments now averaging 10–15 pages of instructions also included both coding and written work. As far as I know, previous years did not require coding in the homework. While this was manageable, the class also had group projects, each accompanied by a 10-page instruction sheet. This required weekly group meetings, which were manageable on their own. However, when combined with the homework, it became a lot of work. Honestly, it felt more like busy work 

I was particularly annoyed because the homework didn’t seem to translate into what we learned in class. The syllabus needs improvement, especially in terms of correcting assignment deadlines and balancing the workload. Prof. Smith is cramming too much into the class. While I understand his LOVE for the design process, he needs to keep in mind that this is a UI course, not a combination of UI and UX. had fun listening to him but it just felt like this was for a different class. 

On average, we had to go through 20–25 pages of instructions a week, considering both individual and group assignments.There was a lack of transparency in this class, for ex. on Edstem, some questions that had 6+ votes up would not be answered for 4 days. The TA didn’t seem to be in the loop much and it felt like Prof. Smith didn’t properly communicate with them about the assignments.
reviews.workload:
5 Assignment that were 10~15 pages long. 
1 semester long project (starts early October) please make sure you know who u want to work with
Grading is fine, at the end of the semester he said most ppl are getting As 

Honestly, I think my year was an odd year, he is trying to revise the syllabus by adding more code/application so it will prob be better next year. But I do not think this is a chill class compared to what other reviews stated

reviews.content: I cannot recommend Prof. Smith's class enough. He's very approachable and his lecture content is really interesting; he does a wonderful job at keeping us engaged and at keeping the broader focus (human-centered design) in the picture during each lecture. Prof. Smith is truly one of the best professors I've had in college.
reviews.workload:
The workload for this class is very, very doable. 

We had short reflections that are due every week. We also split up into groups fairly early on in the semester; these are the groups that we worked in to develop our final product, a UI for an app/website with a distinct audience and purpose. 

We had group checkpoints due every few weeks to ensure that we would work through different prototypes and user studies for our projects throughout the semester. We're also encouraged to meet with our assigned TAs after each checkpoint to get verbal feedback on our projects; the TAs are incredibly helpful. They ensured that we were making good progress during each checkpoint.

There is no midterm and no final. During our final exam slot, we watched final project presentations. Prof. Smith also has two AMAs each year. Instead of him asking us questions in an exam format, we're encouraged to anonymously ask Prof. Smith questions about academia, industry, adulthood, and even his personal life. He presents himself as a mentor figure during his classes. He has such a broad range of experiences; his AMAs were equal parts amusing and insightful—I'm truly grateful that I was able to get into this class!

Grading is incredibly generous. You don't need to get a 100+ in order to get an A+ in the class.

reviews.content: I was initially skeptical of taking this course with anyone other than Prof. Chilton, however, Prof. Smith did a fantastic job. I took this Fall of 2020 and it was one of the few classes during the pandemic that kept me entertained. Prof. Smith's energy is infectious and he consistently gives energetic lectures. The TAs I interacted with were all very helpful and provided meaningful feedback. I thought the workload was easily manageable and grading was very generous (class average was probably around an A-). I still use a lot of the design skills that were taught and definitely felt like I learned a lot from the class. Overall, an interesting class with a great professor/TAs and fair grading, definitely recommend it.

I liked Hadi, he was a very kind professor. I also liked how everyone else in the class was quite passionate about the subject. Coding assignments were fun, some were harder than others, taking from 5 to 30 hours depending on which one... I also liked how the final exam was only 20%. Overall, highly recommend this class for being one of my favorite cs classes I've taken so far, I really learned a lot about graphics
reviews.workload: eh not bad, some assignments were kinda time consuming, but they were all quite rewarding. 6-7 assignments in total, one every two weeks. There was also a written final exam.

reviews.content: I am pretty content with the way this course was taught.  Professor Hadi and his TAs are very understanding when it comes to assignments.  Extensions are given out when asked, and a lot of the times Professor Hadi would extend homework deadlines to make sure that we had enough time to actually learn the material.  As the other review mentioned, you learn about ray tracing and pipeline rendering with OpenGL.  Lectures are standard PowerPoints that can be a bit boring as the lecture was from 7-8PM.  I stopped attending lectures midway through the semester.  The first 5 codio assignments are building a ray tracer, starting with a basic one and then adding enhancements like shadows and reflections. The last homework was on pipeline rendering, and to be honest I was carried by a friend for this assignment as my other courses started to ramp up their work. By the end of the semester, I feel like I know the basic steps of how ray tracing works.  My pipeline rendering knowledge is a little shaky though.  I would encourage anyone who is thinking about taking this course to not take it with heavier courses like FUNDIES and CST like I did...if you do, take it with friends who have lighter courses and can help you with the work.  I did not attend a single OH for this course as HWs 1-4 can be solved easily with the textbook's and PowerPoint's pseudocode. Start early on HW5 and HW6!!!
reviews.workload: Grading is 80% HW and 20% Final.  There were 7 assignments on the syllabus, but we only completed 6 as the Professor kept extending the deadlines. They passed our HWs through their own test cases, but we are also supplied with what the final output should look like. So, if your output resembles the correct output, you most likely will get an A on the HW assignments.  The only A that I didn't get was HW6 bc I started really late on it.  EdStem is your BEST friend, a lot of the students helped each other out on there, the TAs didn't respond as much on EdStem towards the end of the semester though.  If you're a procrastinator, you could definitely pull a weekend of all nighters doing this HW.  I spend 3 straight days working on building a sphere (I slept though).  No midterm, one Final. The professor says it is an easy final, but the average was a 65% so I would study.  I received all As and one C on the HWs, and received a 75% on the final exam.  My final grade was an A-

reviews.content: This class honestly made me really sad. I was really excited to take graphics as I have an interest in the subject but the class is just so poorly organized. Professor Fadaifard is super nice and approachable, but his lectures are painfully boring and slow where he just reads off of his incomprehensible slides, which have code errors in them sometimes. The first slideshow said there was a strict deadline policy with points deducted for every late day, but every homework deadline was extended multiple days on the day of the original deadline. We have had no information about what our final exam is going to look like. I feel like I haven't learned very much in this class which has made me pretty sad because I was looking forward to it. The only cool part about the course was the homework assignments and the TA's who were all nice, but disappeared on ed when the deadlines approached.
reviews.workload: 8-30 hours per homework assignment, the last hws took such a long time

reviews.content:
Hadi is a decent lecturer and knows his stuff, having worked for a major film studio.  He makes sure he covers everything in great detail for the recorded lectures, even though only a handful of students were showing up to the class (it was taught late in the evening).  

You will learn how to build an image renderer from scratch using ray tracing in the first 5 homeworks, starting with simple shapes (triangles and spheres), moving on to shadows and reflections, and finally textures and meshes.  The fifth homework assignment is the longest and most difficult, as it involves implementing multiple different concepts:  Texture mapping, triangle meshes, antialiasing, BVH nodes to speed up rendering time. 

A lot of the skeleton code has been completed, and usually the professor has given you some pseudocode in the lecture slides to be able to implement the rest, but there are quite a few things that are unstated and you will need to do some research on your own to be able to complete the assignments.  I found that the discussions on EdStem were very helpful in being able to complete the assignments, as students usually ran into the same problems and would share solutions to them, but you can’t really rely on this as the forum was not very active except around the time when assignments were due and you will need to get a head start on most of them to complete them in time.  The final homework is an introduction to OpenGL, loading multiple triangle meshes in one scene, using linear transformations to scale, line up and rotate the meshes, and implementing Phong shaders.

Overall, I really enjoyed the class and learned a lot.  The creative submissions part was optional but my favorite part of the class, as it gave a break from the coding and math and let me exercise a bit of creativity with 3D modeling.
reviews.workload: The workload is pretty heavy.  You will be given a couple of weeks to do each assignment, but you need to start them early, and many students required time extensions on a lot of the assignments.  The grade is based almost exclusively on these coding assignments (80%) and getting them working correctly.

reviews.content:
I took this class in Fall 2022. This is a pretty tough course in terms of coding, but I came out loving the subject. There are two main things the prof teaches: Ray Tracing and OpenGL. The first set of homeworks makes you gradually build a ray tracer using C++, and the last one focuses on using OpenGL. I slacked off the first half of the class, and had to seriously pull up my socks in the middle of the semester to pass. The thing with the homeworks is that they build on the previous ones, so if you don't understand the previous ones, you're going to be in a lot of trouble for the future ones. So please try to be very dilligent from the very beginning otherwise you're going to have a seriously difficult time (and spend a lot of nights crying wondering if you're going to pass, like me). Going to TA office hours is not optional for this course. You will HAVE to go to them to be able to do the homeworks, because even if you understand overall concepts (which the professor does explain very well), there are a LOT of nitty gritty implementation details that are simply impossible to do unless someone shows you how. You don't even realize there are things you need to do unless they are pointed out. Unfortunately, I only realized this midway through the semester (which is when you're doing the most difficult homework, btw), and went to basically every OH then (IMMENSELY helpful, I cannot stress this enough). Special shoutout to Nathan Wu and Saravanan who were great TAs. Overall though, this class has made me seriously consider the field as a profession. The final was actually pretty easy since it focused on understanding topics as a whole, and not small implementation details. 
The one thing that really kept me going is how good the professor was. He genuinely loves what he's doing, both the field itself and also teaching students. He is also extremely understanding when it comes to the amount of time students need for the homeworks, extending deadlines when he realized that students needed more time for certain assignments. He also held lecs where he invited speakers, had competitions for extra credit (voting based), and just genuinely seemed like he wanted to help whenever you needed it. I was able to talk to him about my progress in class when I was scared I wouldn't pass, and he gave me a lot of pointers on what I could do to get better and assured me that I'd get through if I was able to work on the bonus assignment and the last one, which was easier than the others. He was a visiting prof so I'm unsure as to when he will teach this course again, however. 
I ended up with a B- at the end, which was surprising because I was pretty sure I was going to flunk it. Class is curved. Overall highly recommend this class, but you need to be able to ask for help. Great professor, but the class is going to make you seriously work for it.
reviews.workload:
5 Ray Tracer assignments
1 Bonus Ray Tracer assignement 
1 OpenGL assignment
1 Final

reviews.content: A staple of the Columbia Computer Science Department and John Hui did not disappoint with his debut as a lecturer, I am happy that I took the course with him.
reviews.workload:
7 Homework Assignments throughout the semester worth a total of 35% of the grade
2 Midterm Exams each worth 20%
A Final Exam worth 25%

reviews.content: One of the kindest cs professors I've ever had. He is super understanding and always does his best to help/emphasis the importance of data structures in job interviews. Tries his best to include problems that are similar to those in interviews(definitely appreciated!). Lectures are recorded which is is super helpful. If you having trouble just stop by his office hours, and he will help you work through it.
reviews.workload: two midterms, 8 homework problems(some type of coding assignment based of the data structure of that week), five quizzes(worth like 5 percent total) and one capstone project, that counts as a final(can not go to OH for this).

reviews.content: This was the least effective class I have taken at Columbia. The instruction lacked precision, quality, and professionalism. Compared to Professor Jae’s clear and admirable teaching, this course did not meet the academic standards I expected from Columbia University.
reviews.workload: This course did not reflect Columbia’s usual academic standards. Columbia is generally an admirable institution that values multidisciplinary thinking and intellectual breadth. Professor Jae exemplifies these qualities and sets a strong example for teaching excellence.

reviews.content:
Dr. B is very kind and approachable, but his lectures are genuinely so boring and rather unhelpful at times. He does read feedback, so maybe he'll improve in the coming semesters. In class, he'll just read off slides that go over concepts briefly before bringing up some methods and reading off the man pages, and going through his code. The class is just not organized in a beginner-friendly way; to actually understand what we were doing, I also had to supplement with Jae's notes or consult ChatGPT lol. His class does seem to cover a little more than Jae's class, which seems to focus slightly more on depth.

TLDR: I quite enjoyed his Data Structures class, so I think it's worth it to take Data Structures with Borowski (especially because he's so approachable and easy to talk to), but go for Jae if you're doing AP.
reviews.workload: 7 HWs around every week or two that can be done with a partner (36% of the grade). 3 exams (exam 1 and 2 each 20%, exam 3 24%). Homework took around 10 hours each. Exams were pretty tough.

reviews.content: took him last semester for data structures and hes aight, but advanced programming you should take with jae. this dude straight up had little to no content worth reviewing on his slideshows. no one shows up to class and in one of the video lecture he starts counting and looks up and counts 14 people in his lecture. got so used to watching him in 2x speed on the recorded lecture that going in person for the tests and hearing him speak was disorienting. take this class with jae
reviews.workload: very strict when it comes to grading for tests and if you miss a semicolon you're cooked. homework assignments are aight too

reviews.content:
Dr. B, while a kind person, is an absolutely terrible lecturer. Lectures were boring, hard to follow, and mostly consisted of him poorly introducing a topic, reading the man pages aloud, and then live-coding some program in front of the class for 20 minutes. Lectures were also recorded, so very few people went to class. The course is broader than Jae’s (breadth over depth) and fairly interesting, but teaching quality was honestly just terrible.

This review is AP-specific; I had him for Data Structures and thought he was fine. Overall, I am incredibly grateful that I will never be using any of these topics again and am free()ing this class immediately from my memory.
reviews.workload: Two midterms (20%) and a non-cumulative final (24%). Exams were difficult but fair. Homeworks took 4-8 hours and could be done with a partner.

reviews.content:
Half of my lecture class didn't attend any lectures and didn't attend office hours as they probably needed - they are who are probably complaining about Professor Borowski. Or they never reviewed the lecture slides before/ahead of class. Or they chatgpt the homework assignments. 

This class is simple: Do the work necessary to succeed, and you will. The professor isn't playing any tricks (unlike some other professors you might find at Columbia).
reviews.workload: Workload is hard, but if you're taking any cs core class expecting a light workload, you're going to be in for a shock.

reviews.content: This is probably the most important class to get past any CS interview and your preparation for AP, so it's pretty important. Borowski does an OK job at guiding you through it–not great and not terrible. His explanations are especially not great. He really loses me when he starts reading off code. However, all lectures are recorded and you can rewatch them as many times as needed, which makes up for it. One thing I did like were the HackerRank problems we did, since I think it's useful to develop the intuition to recognize that those problems could be solved by very briefly modifying a data structure or an algorithm covered in class.
reviews.workload: The homeworks ranged from 2-4 hours (definitely on the higher side of that for the theory HWs, while the first two programming assignments were closer to 1). The capstone project was more similar to an AP lab at about 6 hours. The exception to this is the red-black tree assignment. Get started on that EARLY. Your worse midterm is graded as 10% of your grade, your better midterm is 15% (one of the midterms is the in-class final). The 8 programming HWs and 4 theory HWs are 45% total and the final capstone project is 25%. The remaining 5% are quizzes which are literally a free 10/10 (they are take home and you get 2 attempts). The first midterm was pretty long and a lot of the class did not finish, so the second midterm (final) was easier. Both had an average of low-to-mid 60s. Fortunately, they carry little weight, so the class is a pretty easy B+ or better if you know what you're doing.

reviews.content: Brian Borowski is a very kind professor who seems genuinely invested in the success of his students. He goes over the topics in depth with multiple examples to ensure that you have a good understanding of the material and always relates the content of the course to real world applications (especially as they relate to technical interviews). He always makes an effort to get to know his students so I would 100% recommend going to office hours if you need help. The content of this course can sometimes be difficult but if you study and pay attention to everything he says in lectures then you'll be fine.
reviews.workload: Multiple coding assignments/quizzes/written assignments, but the grading was mostly fair and the averages were usually very high. Be careful with how you submit though because the rubric is quite picky when it comes to that. My only criticism is that the assignments were very technical and gave you a good understanding of how a concept works, but not so much how to implement it in a real application.

reviews.content: Idk who hired this guy and why.
reviews.workload: The assignments are poorly constructed and take up too much time. Worst course plan ever.

reviews.content: Amazing professor! Super nice and friendly - he'll answer any question you have!
reviews.workload: A lot of work but necessary to learn

reviews.content: Professor B is a nice and good intentioned person but he is very very bad at lecturing. He does not spend enough time explaining the different new functions during code walkthroughs and does at best a mediocre job during theory slides. He is quite helpful on edstem though. That being said, it could also just be due to AP's difficult nature but I always just found it to be a cop out excuse for bad teaching. I seriously don't understand how or why Columbia gets lecturers who cannot lecture like you are not even doing research...
reviews.workload: Assignments were ok. 6 in class quizzes comprising 40% and 6 programming assignments comprising 55%, other 5 being attendance. Probably spent around 20-30 hours on this class. Quizzes were not a really good metric for coding ability and felt more like brain teasers with little practical application.

reviews.content: While Dr. Borowski may be seen as strict in his grading, it will definitely prepare you for more advanced programming classes, such as Advanced Programming. He goes over both conceptual and programming skills very well and is overall a nice guy. His TA's were great as well and his organization made help very accessible.
reviews.workload: Grading was fair, feedback was provided. He will say this at the beginning of the class but remember to have all outputs correct (i.e spacing, capitalization, etc) and files submitted as requested! Spent 1-2 hours on most assignments, going upwards to 4 on the harder ones. Two in class midterms, weekly assignments (theoretical or programming), occasional online quizzes, and a final project.

reviews.content: I feel like a lot of people don't like Professor Borowski but I thought he was perfectly fine and I really enjoyed this class. He was good at explaining things and since he was new he actively welcomed feedback about how to make the class better / be a better teacher. Also his office hours are very helpful. I recommend taking this class in your freshman year so you are prepared for the internship recruiting cycle in August.
reviews.workload: It's a hard class but worth it!

reviews.content: I took this class his first semester teaching it and thought it was good. People say AP is so hard but I didn't think it was that bad. He let us work on every programming problem set with a partner which made things much easier and I thought it was a great move because it taught me how to use GitHub collaboratively and how to work collaboratively on code with a team! Not sure if he's still allowing partners though. I also thought the content was so interesting. He also had plenty of practice exams and TA review sessions for the exams.
reviews.workload: 5-10 hours per week. Go to office hours!!!!!!

reviews.content:
I expected to learn a lot about Data Structures, and I admit that I know now a lot more than I did at the beginning of the semester, but that was mainly because I worked extremely hard on my own and went to many office hours to understand the content and do the assignments rather than take a lot from Dr. Borowski's lectures. Professor Borowski is not a great lecturer.

He is not excellent at explaining things in class, and he struggles to gain the attention of all the students because he mostly reads from the slides and does not give any explanations that may add to the content in any way.

The problem is that Dr. B and the TAs may not be very helpful.

Once in his office hours, Dr. B struggled with helping a student debug their code. Similarly, once a TA gave us a problem that he had originally said would take us 15 minutes to solve, and when he did that same problem during recitation, it took him 1 hour and 20 minutes to do the same. Also the class size is very large, so we had to wait hours for debug a single problem out of nine problems on each assignment.

However, Dr. B didn't effectively convey the content. A good number of his assignments are focused on coding the basic implementations of the methods for Data Structures, such as binary search trees, AVL trees, and hash maps. In my opinion, this is not a good thing because he did not give us enough practice using the method implementations to code more complex methods. This problem with the assignments is especially bad when you are practicing for coding interviews.
reviews.workload:
Workload:
12 assignments (45%, lowest grade dropped)
A Capstone Project (25%)
Quizzes (5%, lowest grade dropped)
Two Midterm Exams (lowest grade 10%, higher grade 15%)


Dr. B's workload is awful. He gives many assignments. His first Midterm Exam was in October, and his second Midterm Exam was on the last day of classes. Then, after the second Midterm, you had one week to complete a Capstone Project during the other final exams. That is a lot!
 
He often deducts marks for silly things, such as using additional space in the answers.
 
Dr. B gave 9 late days throughout the semester for 12 assignments in total. You cannot use late days on the Capstone Project and two of the theoretical assignments. Dr. B is not lenient with providing extensions. He provided class-wide extensions on two of the assignments, which led to work management issues as deadlines for them were pushed to be one or two days before the midterms.
 
Additionally, I have heard of a student who spent the whole week working on the Capstone project, and as a result, she did not have enough time to study for her final exams. She made a mistake in her submission, which was that she submitted an entire file instead of the specified code snippet, so Dr. B did not accept her work and gave her a 0. Her class grade went down to a C-. Each week, I spent around ten to fifteen hours on the assignments for this class, and if I had an exam or a quiz, I would spend even more time studying.

reviews.content: Very kind and helpful professor. Despite the large class size, he tries his best to assist every student.
reviews.workload: Heavy but fair workload. 5-10 hours per week.

reviews.content: Dr. B is an excellent professor. While I had some knowledge of data structures going into the course, meaning that I can't comment as someone learning the material totally for the first time, I believe he did a good explaining concepts and was very open to answering questions. He or his TAs also responded promptly to every question on EdStem, which was very helpful because there was less pressure on understanding everything just during class time. Dr. B is polite, funny, and very knowledgeable about his course. It's clear he cares about his students and their learning.
reviews.workload: As someone who went into the course with some familiarity with the material, I did not think the assignments were super difficult, but I can see how they could be more challenging for others. That being said, the median grades are quite high, and you almost always have a week to complete them, so you have time to be confused, ask questions, and figure things out. Grading could be strict, with lots of extra test cases, but it was always fair and logical.

reviews.content:
I'll preface this by saying that after taking both Data Structures and AP with him, I don't think Dr. Borowski is a particularly good teacher, and if you can, you 100% should take the class with Jae Lee instead. But that feels too mean, because I actually quite like him as a person. He can be a bit "funny" in class and on EdStem, is very easy to talk to in office hours, and works very hard (on more than one occasion he typed out very detailed responses to questions he got in class). However, I didn't come out of the class - both classes - feeling like I *learned* anything at all. I definitely memorized a lot of things - all of which I have completely forgotten now that the course is over - but I never got to see why things work the way they do, and never really came close to achieving a big-picture view of the class. I think the "weekly quizzes" section of the class grade was pointless given that its intention was to encourage attendance. I know I'm going to sound arrogant here, but I really think the homework assignments were too easy. At best they helped me improve my pattern-matching skills, because very similar work was already done during class. Add in the fact that we worked on them with a partner, and I didn't spend more than 5 hours on any of the 7 homeworks. The exams are a horrifying joke; to study for them, I recommend you find a way to somehow download the Linux man pages of every single function you ever used in class, homework assignments, or recitations into a memory cache in your brain (this is an exaggeration), but this is a feature of any AP class you take anyways.

All in all, I definitely don't feel ready to take OS with Nieh at all, despite getting an A in this class. God save my soul.
reviews.workload: 7 (should've been 8) homework assignments (45%), 2 midterms (10% and 15%), weekly quizzes (5%), and a final (25%). If you attend class, homeworks should take 4-6 hours to complete as a group, and you get a few late days. The exams will frustrate you if you haven't done systems programming before this class, whether you study intensely or not. Class median is curved to a B/B+.

reviews.content: This is my second CS class with the first being Data Structures, also with Dr. Borowski, so it's hard for me to compare him to other professors. Advanced Programming is, as expected, hard, much harder than Data Structures. However despite the difficulty I still feel like the class was pretty rewarding. You will be forced to learn a lot in this class. While I found the content rewarding, my main complaint is that i felt like the tests were too unfair. I felt like some conent which was covered minimally in class was sometimes given significantly more points than they should have, so if you don't know it you lose a lot of points. He records his classes which makes going over lectures pretty easy.
reviews.workload: 7 homeworks (45%), 2 midterms (10% and 15%), weekly quizes (5%), and a final (25%). Homeworks are made with a partner and took about 8 hours to complete each. Certain number of late days are allowed for homeworks. I felt like exams were graded somewhat unfairly. Class is supposed to be curved (though by how much or what method I don't know at this point).

reviews.content: Borowski's course load was fair. Data structures is not an easy topic and the class was challenging at times, but Borowski always listened to input and was flexible. Also, he tries his best to be engaging and teach difficult topics with simple explanations. Much of the class received an A or A-, so accusations of poor grading are really unfounded (the curve was not harsh at all). Finally, Borowski is very approachable in general (many people would stop and ask him questions after class, while he genuinely tried to explain/help however he could). Just make sure to know Java before you start, put in the work, and you'll be fine.
reviews.workload: Weekly assignments that can take 4-8 hours (10 max). 2 midterms (1 is dropped), 1 final project (which was not much more intricate than the weekly assignments)

reviews.content: Very sweet guy, tries to be funny and entertaining to keep the mood light in class, very intelligent man btu course is def catered towards peopel with [revious data structures experience. Can be very hard to keep up in class without feeling overwhelmed so most of my learning was done by rewatching lectures and pausing to take notes slowly. Programming projects were challenging but definitly doable, especially with the help of TAs, midterms were difficult but also most of the content tested was expected, only a few questions felt out of the blue. Offered extra credit assignments to help students. Would disagree when people say he was too stubborn and isn't open to feedback because he actively asked for feedback at many benchmark times in the course and also shifted things like hw deadlines, midterm grade boost opportunities, extra credit, etc to try and accommodate the biggest things students were asking for. He can't change everything for us and for students to expect that is unreasonable. Overall decent expereince, very challenging for me but I learned a lot and did good work.
reviews.workload: Pretty heavy workload, weekly programming project/theoretical written assignment, 2 midterms, 1 final project

reviews.content: He's a good professor. For context, this is the only class in Java I've taken at Columbia, so I wouldn't be able to compare it to other professors, but he was good. I found coding assignments to be easier than the theoretical ones. Grading  is fair, similar standards to other computer science classes. He's approachable and good at explaining. I did most of my lectures over zoom and it was sufficient to get a good grade. Midterms are time constrained.
reviews.workload:
Weekly assignments
2 Midterms, drops lowest
1 Final project

reviews.content:
1. Unreasonable deadlines
There were assignments due every week, no late hours. He said this is fair because 'the hw with the lowest grade is dropped'.. LMAO. Wouldnt advice on taking this class with other heavy courses (especially if you're new to programming) because this prof acts like his class is the only one his students are taking

2. Really disorganized
People often say the best way to complete assignments on time is by 'starting early'. Well meet this class, where its almost impossible to start early because the coding assignments will be updated as late as one day before its due.

3. 'Industry'
The prof will keep on saying that his unreasonable deadlines and his hackerranks 'teach you what its like in the industry' lol. If you know anything about current coding intrerviews at top companies, you'll understand how out of reach this approach is
reviews.workload: Expect to be spending between 20 - 40 hours per week doing his assignments, especially if you're new to programming. Might take significantly less hours if you already understand data structures and have strong programming fundamentals

reviews.content: Actually liked the content, found it very useful and logical, hated the professor
reviews.workload: Workload was huge at the beginning of the semester, the professor did not know how to run a Columbia CS classes, he gave no late hours, was very stubborn, he assigned way too much homework that literally could not be done alone, each week the programming project took at least 20h if not more, the nice thing was that he provided test cases for most assignments (so you knew how you would probably do on the assignment, however I found it stress inducing because you were spending so much time getting all the test cases to work), the TA office hours were always super crazy (since nobody could do the assignment alone), I think he did not guess the time commitment for each assignment correctly, this class almost made me burn out, then there was also a mess with the grading, basically he replaced the final with a second midterm on the last day of classes (so basically a final) AND a final project which I know will take forever, he is so stubborn and not open to any feedback, I hate this class even though I enjoyed the material, he would also make you do Hackerranks in class which I found to take up too much time and was not helpful in learning the material, he also did not release solutions to HWs which was frustrating because sometimes you did not know what you did wrong

reviews.content: Didn't expect much from this class because I had no prior knowledge about it, but am really glad I took it. It's a great connection between CS and art, which is something I've always been looking for. Prof. Santolucito is so clearly knowledgable and also very understanding as a person. Would definitely recommend since there isn't another CS course like this that I think is offered. Definitely on the easier side, you get what you put into the course.
reviews.workload: More assignments in the first half of the semester and it tones down after that. Uses javascript. No exams, just homework (not weekly) and a final project. Most exciting/fun part is live coding

reviews.content: Computational Sound was definitely a class on the easier side, and Mark is a really good professor who always answers my questions during his office hours really thoroughly. Although I loved the projects I worked on for that class and really put in the effort into it, I didn’t learn as much as I wanted to from the lectures and feel like I could have learned the information taught on my own.
reviews.workload: Easy workload - Assignments 60%, Participation 10%, Final project 30%

reviews.content: I took this class because it started off so easily. I love Jan, he is such a kind soul and so patient and really helpful. He’s a great teacher and can easily break down concepts and make it more digestible. His office hours are where he really shines. He is a bit too soft spoken and at times not a very dynamic lecturer like Blaer for example. But he can out teach Jae, and Blaer.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: I didn’t spend that much time, I didn’t even go to class too often because he had a zoom option and his notes were always great.

reviews.content: I took Mobile App iOS Development with Prof. Thomas this past semester (Fall 2024). I thought he was an engaging lecturer, and I liked how he would code sample apps or functionalities in-class. Admittedly, it felt like he passed through writing the code a bit quickly to the point where it was a bit tricky to follow along, but I just deferred to the slides that he presented with to fill in the gaps. The demos also didn’t work the most consistently, but I understand things can happen at times. I also really appreciated the guest lecturers that worked for Apple that he invited for one of the classes. The policies for the class were very lenient (such as how students could borrow MacBooks if they didn’t own one) and I would say somewhat paralleled User Interface Design in the sense that we were encouraged to search code snippets and use ChatGPT to aid in the creation of the assignments. The reasoning behind it appeared to also parallel UI – project-based, and graded based on the nature of the product as opposed to incorporating exams and being based on the content of the code used to create a product (and by extension, forbidding ChatGPT and other AI tools). He and the TAs were very approachable and lenient with grading the HW regarding deadlines – I accidentally forgot to push a change I made to GitLab (which we worked on) for one of the assignments, so I shows it to the TAs, and they gave me credit for the changes once I pushed! All in all, I really liked learning Swift through this course and it definitely helped demystify it for me.
reviews.workload: We had four homework assignments (50%), then a “fifth” one that was our team project (40%), then attendance with 4 allowed excused absences (10%). The four homeworks involved implementing smaller apps in Swift using XCode – basic Storyboard implementations, editable table view with accompanying detail views, usage of an API to display data in a table, and usage of the MapKit to implement a Map that shows data form an API. For the team project, we had to come up with a project idea to make in Swift, program it, then make a video presenting it. It was admittedly intensive for the time we had to work on it and I admittedly would have preferred some of the time for the homeworks instead being allotted to working on the final project (similarly to User Interface Design). Additionally, the time to work on the milestones (along the lines of coming up with ideas/features, creating a MVP, creating the full app, final touch ups) felt a bit lopsided. Then, the last two milestones definitely took longer than the first two, but all four only had an allotted week. Beyond that, I thought it was a very doable class to get an A (or even A+) in!

reviews.content: This course gave me my first A+ at Columbia.  Professor Hugh and the TAs are gems and so is this course.  Throughout this course, you learn about IOS app development using swift or swift storyboard.  You need a MacBook for this course or someway to access Xcode.  The first half of the semester consists of 4 HW assignments where you learn how to create a weather app, use API calls, and build an app with a Map feature.  They break down all of the requirements with no hidden test cases, so you know exactly what you need to build to receive full credit.  Because I was taking heavier courses with this one, I started most of my HWs the night before they were due and stayed up until 5AM to complete them.  All HWs are due before class time, which was 4:10PM for me.  The second half of the semester consisted of a group project.  My group had a lot of issues, but we were transparent with the Prof and TAs who were very understanding.  You present your group project to the class, the TAs, Professor Hugh and some of his colleagues from Apple and Google!  If you're into networking this was a great experience for that.  But yeah, 10 out of 10 course.  Definitely take! The only issue with this course is Xcode, it is truly an awful app, and Apple needs to work on it.
reviews.workload:
1) Individual assignments (4 or 5 during the semester) (total 50%) 
     - deducts 50% if one minute late -- BUT my friend submitted his HW late, had a 50% on it for the whole semester, and then they changed it to a 100% at the end of the semester (he didn't get an A+, I don't know if it was for other reasons though like attendance, but he did get an A)
2) Team Project (total 40%)
     - There is a whole rubric, but I think they give everyone 100s if everything is completed and the app is functional
3) Class attendance* (total 10%) - he didn't start taking attendance until the end of the course, so I would start attending consistently during team projects
TAKE THIS COURSE

reviews.content:
If you love systems programming (AP/OS/C/Assembly) this class is for you.

The class is co-taught by Jae Woo Lee.

Expect to learn a lot more about Userspace Linux Internals.

Hans is an amazing, very engaging professor. I would recommend the class to those who love systems.
reviews.workload: 6 Homework Assignments. Expect to spend 10+ hours on the homework. Expect to go to office hours often, the TAs are your saving grace. 1 Midterm and 1 Final.

reviews.content: Imagination

course_header.course_name: Topics in Computer Science: Cloud Computing and Big Data

reviews.workload: The coding homeworks are not bad at all. A few ungraded exercises here and there to help with conceptual content absorption. The exams are not supposed to be bad, but they give you a tiny bit of anxiety because the exams are basically the first time when you apply the theoretical concepts learned in class. Professors like to do this... what can I say.

reviews.content:
The class is all about using AWS services to make web apps. You just need to make things work and show them to get marks. Lots of time is wasted in debugging and doing silly things that don't teach you cloud computing, but just DEBUGGING.

The cloud concepts are somewhat covered in lectures partially and you are expected to learn yourself too through readings assigned every week.

Overall, a good but unorganized course with more workload than it is supposed to have. You will definitely learn about many cloud technologies and will be able to make simple cloud apps that can impress someone.

If you have time to code and do a super project oriented course in a semester, take this course!

course_header.course_name: Topics in Computer Science: Cloud Computing and Big Data

reviews.workload:
10 papers
2 quizzes
3 small projects
1 final project

reviews.content: If you want to learn the deep theoretical foundations of control systems, I strongly recommend taking courses with Professor Beigi. Even if you are not familiar with control, that's completely fine. He begins the course with fundamental math needed to understand the course material (It is definitely helpful, though, to review calculus and differential equations beforehand). He is very open to students and truely care each of students in the class. When I ask a question, he is always happy to explain further and makes sure I understand the concept. His expertise extends far beyond control. With his research experience in areas such as speech recognition, deep learning, and robotics, he can teach you research skills and guide you toward cutting-edge research.
reviews.workload: His assignment is very creative. He makes each assignment that connects class theories to real-world problems. If you take his course, you will immediately learn how to implement control theories to any practical applications. The homework load gets heavy as the midterm approaches, but this is meant to prepare you. He is also generous in grading. He care much more about your reasoning and approach than trivial mathematical mistakes.

reviews.content: Professor Beigi is an excellent professor, and clearly very knowledgeable and passionate about his craft. He is also one of the most approachable and kind professors I have taken a class with at Columbia. It is important to note (and he states this at the beginning at the class) that this is a math course, and should be taken with this expectation in mind. However, he makes the math very comprehensive, and spends a good amount of time building a foundational background at the beginning of the course to help with the content in the latter parts of the class. The exams were fair, and the homeworks were not too time consuming.
reviews.workload: Homeworks bi-weekly, One midterm worth 30%, one final worth 40%, relatively manageable courseload overall.

reviews.content: Imagine you are trying to learn control systems, but instead, you first spend several lectures reviewing every single detail of linear algebra, complex analysis and without any context for how it applies to control systems. Then, when you actually start talking about control systems, only discuss it in the most theoretical terms while barely giving any examples or practice. Oh, and did I mention that this class is not even going to test you on proofs or anything?? And as a final straw, instead of accepting feedback and changing the curriculum, the professor instead blames the students.
reviews.workload: The homeworks were pretty much a waste of time, involving mainly proofs and very little practice. One egregious example is the first homework, where you had to go up and down an elevator four times.I spent a few hours a week on homework for this class.

reviews.content: Here's the gist in short: It is an easy A- class (he believe only the best projects deserve an A). You will not learn much because he's lectures are a justification for his influence on modern C++ and he doesn't really teach you anything. It is interesting, but I would spent my money differently on a more relevant class.

course_header.course_name: Topics in Computer Science: Language Library Design

reviews.workload: Easy as a humanity class. However, the project can be easy or hard as you choose. For a good grade, you should have a serious project.

reviews.content:
Prof. Stroustrup's lectures are dry, but he makes up for it by having incredible stories about his days at Bell Labs, or on the ISO cpp standards committee. Unlike some other famous programmers, Prof Stroustrup is incredibly approachable - probably one of the kindest people I know - always willing to chat about languages or computers. My view of C++'s features and purpose have been totally changed - seriously, take this course if you know a little bit of C++ (say, from advanced programming) and want to learn more. It's simply amazing to have someone with Prof. Stroustrup's experience teaching at Columbia - safe to say that this course was the highlight of my semester. 

If you take this course, make sure you get a picture with him at the end.

course_header.course_name: Topics in Computer Science: Language Library Design

reviews.workload:
It starts out light - you do some performance testing on different ways to sort things. 

2nd half of the semester things pick up, because the class project is assigned. The day before they were due, my group and I worked on it from 10:30 AM to 6 AM the next day - but it was SO worth it.

reviews.content:
I absolutely loved this class. It literally caused me to excel in my other classes, and regain hope in Columbia CS. The professor is kind and hilarious. I actually learned a lot, and didn't wipe it out of my brain after the class. 

Prof Ferguson both gives readings, visual demonstrations (through graphing how data would flow), gives slides, and doesn't walk alongs. He also records classes. There is a lot of content, but it is very approachable because he explains conceptually how it works very clearly and so even though there is a lot of technical new skills you have to learn, they seem obvious given the conceptual understanding. Also gets easier given the amount of both practice through homework and in class examples. 

He is very approachable, kind, and genuinely seems to care. It is both his personality and teaching style that literally made be excited to go to class, and even do the homework. He is my far the best professor in the CS department and dare I say all of SEAS.
reviews.workload:
Grading: 50% homework, 20% midterm, 30% final 
There is a homework assignment about every 2 weeks. (average for CS dept.) 
His grading was very fair. He didn't have extremely strict formatting, and there was room for creativity, but it was clear what he was looking for in the homeworks. 
About 4-5 for homework but more time for reviewing notes and class as you are completing the homework since there is a lot of content.

reviews.content:
I wish I had checked culpa reviews before taking this class. The reviews on here are old , but they're all true. Prof. Levine is the worst professor I've had at Columbia by far. She is not empathetic and assumes the worst intentions in all her students. On top of that, she does not know how to give constructive feedback, or just even any feedback at all. She will criticize the work you turn in by literally saying "I don't even know where to begin with how bad this is" and then continues to not even outline what the problem is. When we meet with her outside of class to go over her feedback, she is still extremely vague as to what she wants. This class in theory and in content is simple, but pleasing Prof. Levine felt like an impossible task the entire semester. 

She is condescending and not once have I felt like a professor didn't want their students to succeed. 

If you want to do well its going to be emotionally draining and physically time consuming. Even though my group ended up with a good grade in the class, I would seriously not take this if I could go back in time.
reviews.workload:
Weekly 2 discussion posts (each ~300 words), 3 assignments and one semester long project in groups of 2-3.

many hours a week on the project

reviews.content: Do not, and I mean DO NOT, take a class with this professor. Not only is she a bad teacher, but I don't think I've ever taken a course where I felt like the professor truly did not want to see us succeed. Prof Levine spent an entire semester individually threatening to fail everyone. She would constantly be aggressive, rude, and degrading in all interactions that students would have with her. She would also frequently forget things she’d said and then penalize students for it. I’m not sure why and how this professor is still able to teach, but if you want to spend a semester pandering to someone whose goal is to give you a hard time, take this class.
reviews.workload: Weekly discussion posts, 3 assignments, group project. Extremely hard to figure out what she wanted for the group project. No assignment had a rubric, so you could pretty much receive any grade.

reviews.content: This course covers "big data" including research methods in traditional lab based research and how it translates to scraping data from the web. Had some interesting conversations about ethics. Class lectures were moderately interesting, but you could also do other stuff if needed because there are no tests and slides get posted. Overall mid class, could be very helpful if you want to do research teaches a lot about methods and how to conduct studies using big data, forming hypothesis, some basic stats, presenting your findings ect. Professor was pretty open to meeting outside of class to help with project.
reviews.workload:
3 homework assignments (10% each) the first one was a literature review that was graded the most harshly (but opportunity for a redo if you did bad).
Weekly Online Discussion Board (1-3 topics posted by classmates per week, have to read article and then answer question prompts and write response for full credit each week. Final project that includes doing a "big data" research project mostly groups of two but a few groups of three and a few people worked alone. You got to pick your topic and she helped with group forming. Presented at the end and most of the topics were pretty interesting and creative. Grading got done within a week for almost everything which was nice.

reviews.content:
She is the worst "professor" I've ever encountered at Barnard. She should be fired. When I graduate in a few years, I intend upon writing a letter outlining the various reasons why she's a bad instructor and how she ruins the lab experience. She's the kind of professor that makes me not want to donate to this school, ever.

She is not clear. She does not explain anything well, and expects her students to magically figure out what she was TRYING to say.

Not only that, she is crazy, mean, and unfair. The only way you're going to do well in this class is if you are a gifted academic, a senior, a psych major, or a total suck up - with emphasis on the latter.

An example: this semester, she randomly broke out in a yelling fit because she felt not enough people were participating during the mental rotation lab. She literally made a girl cry. Keep in mind that this lab class is full of people who don't know psychology well (no less understand the complexities of MENTAL ROTATION) and are just trying to fill the requirement. Most don't have anything insightful to say, and if they did, they wouldn't know when or how to say it because she is so unbelievably unclear.

Oh and by the way, she'll try and dock points off of your grade in any way she can. If she doesn't like you (she picks and chooses random people to not like), you're screwed.

The bottom line is you should stay far away from her if you can. If you can't, suck up to her.
reviews.workload: papers every week. labs every week.

reviews.content:
Wow, these reviews are incredibly cruel and unfair. I want to preface this by saying that I am neither a psychology major nor adept at any form of science. I took this class merely to fulfill the science requirement. I was pleasantly surprised by how well this class went. 
 I thought professor Levine was very clear in her lectures, almost too clear sometimes. She always took time to explain concept and answer questions. Unlike another professor who substituted for her a few times. She also clearly made an effort to make the material seem interesting by bringing in a flutist, discussing her own research, and having us participate in fun activities in class. 
Yes, we were required to know more information than was discussed in class: this seems like a standard practice, the previous psych courses I took had the same format. 
The exams were challenging as they should be in a college setting. What compensated for this though was the generous curve. Grades in the 74 range, the class median, were curved to an A-. 
As for the lab, yes, it was long and drawn out, in my mind as all labs should be. But the experiments involving the mberry pill and the final experiment which we designed ourselves were quite interesting. For all the labs, instructions were clearly laid out. There were no surprises. 
I think Levine is a pretty good professor.
reviews.workload:
Lecture: three exams
Lab: weekly assignments, final lab report

reviews.content: After having two semesters with this professor, my advice to you is to stay far far away. The alternative in the psychology major (neuroscience) is not only easier, but taught by a far better professor. It becomes clear in class that Professor Levine does not really have a clear handle on what she is teaching. Her tests do not reflect what she teaches at all. Overall, a really unclear class with no clear objectives. Additionally, she does not make it seem like she enjoys teaching whatsoever.
reviews.workload: 3 midterms

reviews.content: She is a really bad professor and is very partial to students that she likes. Her class and lab are very boring and she takes off points for the stupidest reasons. I think she spends at least 30 minutes each lab with her TA to talk about how every word should be equally spaced and every page number and should be in the same font. This class is mind-numbing. I don't think she realizes that she's teaching a class full for college students and not elementary school. And please she needs to stop with stories about her dog.
reviews.workload: Workload isn't hard just really monotonous and she takes off points for almost everything.

reviews.content: Professor Levine is a terrible professor. She refuses to answer questions, often promising to answer them later and never getting to them. She does not cover a lot of what she puts on the exams. It's not uncommon to hear her say "We won't go over this in class, but be sure to review it for the exam" -- this is not for one or two concepts, but could include as many as 10 outside articles that she will never address. Her exams are a crapshoot, it's impossible to figure out what will be on them. She gives you a "fair game sheet" but then most of it is "study entire chapter" which is not very helpful at all. In lab she is rude and likes to take points off for little things. For instance, she will take points off if your page numbers on your lab report are in the wrong font, never mind that the content of the report is great. It is very hard to connect with her, and as the last post mentioned, she is not at all engaging. She comes in to class ready to "get it over with" and doesn't really care about the success of her students. I'm confused as to why she is a professor -- she must really hate her job and students in general. Being in her class is painful, and I can't wait till it's over.
reviews.workload: three midterm exams, each weighted the same. nothing else.

reviews.content: Just wanted to warn you off this woman, because no one warned me.  Actually, no, I asked a friend about her, and my friend said she's cool--apparently that's only if she really likes you.  Maybe she is actually a perfectly decent person but my friends' and my experience with her this semester was not good at all.  I don't want to say anything too identifying, but she badly handled a situation with a friend of mine who made an honest mistake on an assignment--to take a lot of points off is one thing, but to also use needlessly harsh language with her?  Apart from that, she also just isn't good at engaging her students, and the assignments are bizarre ("write a discussion section of a lab report pretending that you did this experiment when really you totally didn't lol").  I did well on all the assignments--that isn't my problem.  Just take this lab with caution.
reviews.workload: negligible--not the point!

reviews.content: lectures aren't recorded but he posts his notes before each class, so you can download the jupyter notebook file and follow along with his example code in class and also play around with the code yourself. he teaches topics at a reasonable pace and at the start of each class, he does a brief review of material covered in the previous class. overall, he's a very very nice guy

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
1 exercise set every 2-3 wks: 3 total, graded on completion. each consists of 3-4 free response questions and 3-4 coding problems, some are pretty fun! (e.g. hangman, blackjack) if you just sit down one day and lock in on it, you could get it done in 2-4 hours.
3 group projects (3 people, you can fill out a form to choose your group member preferences): present to a TA by explaining your code, takes a considerable amount of time (collectively, 10 hrs? maybe more) so don't procrastinate and keep reminding your group to get their stuff done.
3 midterms, no final: midterms are 6 FRQs and not overly challenging, partial credit given, he provides a list of topics and goes over them during the class before the midterm

reviews.content: The course is definitely interesting if you are in NLP and the professor is both kind and a good instructor, but the structure of the class was a bit lacking. The lectures, ungraded assignments, and the exams are theoretical, while HW is applied (writing actual Python). What this means is that the lectures don't prepare you very well for the homework and the homework doesn't prepare you very well for exams. Howevre, he ungraded assignments definitely help with the exam but the homework IS fundamentally based on a concept from lecture. The homeworks are also pretty fun. A bigger issue was slow grading. I'm taking the course during the summer which means no midterm, only a final worth 40%. The only graded feedback we have received so far was the first homework based on lectures 3 and 4 out of 19. We are supposed to at least get the second HW graded before the final but we will see.
reviews.workload: Workload is reasonable. 6% participation but this is graded nicely. 4 HWs worth 18% each for a total of 54% with one dropped. 40% final. Note that this is for the summer course. The semester course definitely has a midterm, and I believe it has additional HW assignments that we skip in the summer as well.

reviews.content: I expected this class to be more beginner friendly than it was. I came from no experience. It was alright, and I did manage to do well, however, it took a lottt of practice outside of class and finding resources on my own. While Bauer is a super nice guy and really wants all his students to succeed, I also did not understand his method of teaching. It seems more example heavy than overarching rule heavy (which is how I learn to apply to other examples). Still, his class was fair, just I felt that I struggled a lot in it.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: 4 problem sets, 3 midterms (the final is technically a midterms), and 3 group projects contributed to your grade. This class was not a huge time commitment at all if you didn't need extensive practice outside of class. For me, I found that I did need that extra practice, however, the work actually assigned to me was super manageable.

reviews.content:
Professor Bauer is a warm and kind person who creates a welcoming environment for all kinds of questions. He’s always available to answer them, whether in class, during office hours, or on Ed. He also has a large team of TAs, so if you’re struggling with a concept, there’s plenty of support available. He’s also very understanding and approachable.
The class is well-organized. He uses Jupyter Notebook (which he posts after class) for lectures and runs code on it to demonstrate concepts step by step. During lectures, he’s happy to answer questions, (even after class too).
The homework and projects aren’t too difficult, but it’s important to start early to give yourself time to think through them and ask questions if needed. The homework does a good job of preparing you for the types of questions he gives on exams. He dedicates an entire class to review before each exam, which is really helpful.

Lectures can sometimes feel a bit dry, and I found myself nearly falling asleep a few times. Also, exams and PSets take too long to grade.

Overall, Professor Bauer is a great instructor who cares about his students and provides plenty of resources to help them succeed.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
4 Individual Exercise Sets (ES) ->	20% (5% each, material covered in class)
3 Group Projects -> 24% (8% each) (You work in a group of 3 that you can choose. Start early so that you have time to ask questions. After submitting, you need to present the project to a TA. The TAs are chill)
3 Exams -> 54% (18% each, as the last one is final) (Start early, go over the lectures and the review done in class. He also provides you with a list of topics included. The final was really tough, while the first two exams were fair. He might curve if needed)
Exercise Set 0	-> 2%

reviews.content:
I expected the class to be pretty simple because I’ve taken Python before and I’m an intended CS major. I learned too late that you could skip out of the class, so I used it as a refresher since I hadn’t coded in Python in a couple of years.

Bauer's teaching style is great. He shares his screen to show his code and works through notes in Jupyter Notebook (posted after class), which is super clear. Don’t be afraid to ask questions or participate in class, he's really receptive and willing to explain logic multiple times or in different ways until you understand.

The content is fine overall. If you’ve never coded before, it might feel like a lot to learn in one semester, but if you take the course somewhat seriously, you’ll have a solid understanding of Python and computer science basics.

For those who’ve programmed or learned Python before, this course is pretty easy. If you want to get ahead, you can skip it (I didn’t because I already had credits for intro Java and didn’t know I could skip until the last minute). But it’s good for a review of Python or starting off with an easier course if that’s what you’re looking for.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload:
4 exercise sets, 5% each, all pass/fail (based on completion)

3 group projects, 8% each, not very long

3 exams, 18% each

Grading was fine overall. Exercise sets were essentially a guaranteed 20% of your grade as long as you attempted and submitted them, and video + code solutions from the TA's were posted. The group projects were manageable, and you could get away with waiting until the last day or two to start if someone in your group had coding experience (they try to balance groups to include at least one experienced coder). Had to meet with a TA to explain your code, but you aren't being quizzed on specifics, so I wouldn't worry too much about it.

For exams, we were given a clear list of topics to know and also specified what wouldn’t be tested. He also emphasized that reviewing the exercise sets was important for exam prep. Exam grading was fair (ex you could get partial credit on questions if you showed your work or logic).

The first two exams were fine, but the final one was more challenging. Even if you did well on the earlier exams, I’d recommend putting extra effort into studying for the final.

The only downside was that grading often took longer than expected. For example, grades that he promised to released in two days sometimes took over a week. Grades came out pretty slowly (even the pass/fail exercise sets), which was a little inconvenient but not a huge issue.

exercise sets: 1-2 hrs every 2 weeks
group projects: ~8 hours total for the first project (adjusting to group work style, felt less structured than the other two), 3–5 hours each for the other two
more time for exam prep, but much less than I would spend for other classes
I would say this class isn't as time-consuming as others, but make sure to acc prep for exams

reviews.content: As someone who came into this class with a lot of experience with Python, I didn't expect it to be challenging. Still, I can admire how well put together the progression of this course is and how well he teaches it. Prof. Bauer is very organized and his lecture notes are really good. Sometimes his lectures can be boring, especially if you already know Python pretty well.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Pretty light compared to other classes. Individual exercise sets are not bad, group projects are manageable, tests are very fair. He publishes all the content that may be on the test beforehand. Take this class with him.

reviews.content: Bauer is a really nice professor, explains things well in lecture, and is helpful during OH. Lectures can be slightly boring especially if you already know Python, but Bauer is a really nice guy and he definitely wants students to succeed because he tries to hint at topics that will be on tests. One thing to note about Python is that there is a group project aspect of this class. Get. A. Good. Group. There’s one chance to switch groups after the first group project is due, but getting a good one in the first place is just better.

course_header.course_name: Introduction to Computer Science for Engineers/Applied Scientists - Python

reviews.workload: Not a big time commitment. 4 exercise sets graded on completion worth 20% of your grade. 3 group projects worth 24% of your grade. You have to present your project to a TA after you submit to make sure that everyone in the group contributed and knows what is going on (this is why it is important to get a good group!!!). Basically, you have to tell them how all the functions work and such. 3 exams worth 54% of your grade. There isn’t a final. Instead, the 3rd exam is on the last day of class before the reading period. Exercise set 0 which is just setting up the software is 2% of your grade.

reviews.content: Great class! Bauer is great at explaining things and a great professor overall! He records all lectures and the recordings are great. Exams are super fair. I found the content to be really interesting especially in the first half of the class, the second half was more about neural networks which bored me a little.
reviews.workload:
HW can be a bit tedious but there's only 5 for the whole semester.
All HW is programming. The exams are non-programming, so the HW doesn't help prepare. Instead the exams are based on lecture content and some non-graded assignments which can make studying a little harder but the exams were chill.
Participation is a part of your grade but I think you get 100 if you just post on Ed at least once.
Overall chill for a CS class

reviews.content:
He's such a nice guy, and as other reviewers have said, he absolutely loves NLP! His passion for the subject tends to overwhelm him and he fails to explain things in a clear manner, because at times I think he gets so engrossed in the subject and assumes that everyone has the same level of understanding as he does. It's almost impossible to understand what he's saying at times, because he moves so fast through the various topics and does not explain things in a very clear way. 

He's great during office hours and he's such a polite and sweet man, that it's hard NOT to like him, but honestly if you're a CS major and looking for an easier course, this is definitely not it! I'd only take this if you have a very strong interest in NLP, or you don't really care too much about what grade you get (he curves, but you really need to know the material for the A).
reviews.workload: This is a course that comes with a heavier workload. Assignments are difficult, because he glosses over the concepts with very little explanation. You have to actively research the material yourself in some cases. It's best to go to the TA office hours and have them explain to you the concepts. Ask them to teach you the concepts, and you should be OK for the homeworks.

reviews.content: Bauer is a nice professor and is super passionate about the topic. I heard great things about the class, but I ended up being very disappointed. He covers far too many concepts and does not explain them well enough so you end up being super confused. The homeworks are doable as they have very detailed instructions. The tests, however, are very unreasonable. He doesn't give any practice problems/practice test so you have no idea what kind of problems he will ask. Would not recommend as the tests are stressful and you don't end up learning much.
reviews.workload:
5 programming assignments, lowest dropped. Manageable, every 2 weeks.
Midterm was a lot harder than he said it would be and he doesn't give any practice tests.
Midterm 20%, final 30%, homework 50%

reviews.content: This was a super chill class. Ross goes much slower than any other CS prof I've ever had. Most of class is introducing a topic, and then slowly working through examples to cover every (corner) case of it, with plenty of time for questions. He records lectures and posts his notes.
reviews.workload:
4 parts of a project that you do in a pair. Parts of the project could be quite tedious and not directly related to course content (for example, spending hours trying to clean up data to insert into your database) but ultimately you end up with a cool end result. 
2 homework assignments
1 midterm 
1 final (cumulative)

reviews.content: He's not a bad professor, but the class itself can be a little boring if you're not into the material. The project is pretty fun to do. People say Ferguson is the best and to avoid Ross, but if you get him you're not too bad off. Midterm and final are all pretty reasonable, and can cram studying for (no study sheets though). This year, because of the protests/campus environment, he made the final a 24-hour take home that was based on your project, so it'd be harder to cheat.
reviews.workload:
The only graded assignments were a project (I strongly recommend you do it with a partner) with four parts. Part 3 (creating a website) took longest, and my partner and I spent probably 36 hours working on it right before the due date (this part was given over a month in advance. If we'd spread out the work and not been sleep deprived, this would take maybe a few hours a week of working at most). Expect to spend maybe 3-6 hours a week, reasonably, on the project? 

Grading was on a curve (there's no info about this online, so I figured I'd post here). This year, the grade cutoffs (uncurved) were as follows: A+ 98, A 91, A- 85, B+ 80, B 76, B- 70, C+ 68, C 65, C- 58, D 45. The project is 30% of your grade, the midterm is 20%, and the final is 50% (if you do better on the final, it replaces your midterm grade). The final was pretty reasonable.

reviews.content: class was confusing, boring, and unstructured, take with anyone else if possible! He drones on and on without passion and it's really hard to learn when it seems that the professor himself has zero interest in teaching and the subject. He also didn't record the lectures. The only good thing about this class was the project, it was quite fun and you learn a lot.
reviews.workload: assignments weren't too bad but some questions were rather confusing because he did a really bad job explaining the concepts in class. roughly ~5 hours per hw assignment? and more for the project.

reviews.content: would not recommend this version of databases - take ferguson! initially, the first half of the semester was fine when it was just SQL, but during the second half of the semester, ross went extremely fast and many students in the class were confused. there was one time during office hours where over 40 students came, because that's how difficult and confusing the homeworks were. he was also extremely vague on ed whenever students asked for help, making the course more confusing. However, i do think this class is definitely manageable if this is your only choice - just make sure to go to class and read the textbook!!!
reviews.workload: project (building database system) 20%, homework 20%, midterm 20%, final 40%

reviews.content: This class is probably GE for most cs majors and my hopes going in is just to finish off with an A and be done with it. The course itself is very proof-based and theoretical. Prof. Chen did a excellent job breaking down the material and the homework were well-designed to prepare us for exams. Exams are fair and 80% went over in class, with 20% requiring some extra thinking that is doable if you understood the proofs in class. He is also a very approachable and understanding person in general. I strongly recommend him if you have similar expectation of the course as me. Very generous curve applied at the end.
